intertextuality bible religion
Itil

The Tatar name of the river Volga. The title of Ilya’s letter “Zaitil’shchina” is derived from this version of the river’s name. Ostanin also suggests a sound link between the rivers Itil’ and Lethe (Leta), the river of oblivion and forgetting, which also plays a major role in Sokolov’s first novel, A School for Fools (10).

foreign language location setting
sting

Stinger (insects’). Animal motif. This could be an allusion to the city of Samara: as you take a look at Volga’s flow, it is precisely in Samara that the course is “stingy.”

motif location Russia
scythe

In the original, “kosa” means at the same time braid, scythe, or sandback/spit. The ambiguity of the word “kosa” has a famous literary “predecessor” in Aleksandr Blok’s drama Balaganchik (The Puppet Show, 1906). The female character of Columbine has a “kosa” behind her back: either a hair braid or a scythe. The “mystics” warn Pierrot about her being Death, but he calls her his bride (“Я не слушаю сказок. Я — простой человек. Вы не обманете меня. Это — Коломбина. Это — моя невеста”; I don’t listen to fairy tales. I am a simple man. You will not deceive me. This is Columbine. This is my bride). The ambiguity is also stressed by the character of the Author who enters the scene and exclaims: “Я не признаю […] аллегорической игры словами: неприлично называть косой смерти женскую косу! Это порочит дамское сословие!” (I do not recognize […] such allegorical wordplay: it is indecent to call a woman’s braid a scythe of death! It denigrates a lady’s status!). In the end, Pierrot sadly discovers that this Columbine was just a “cardboard bride” (Она картонной невестой была). The crucial theme linking a woman’s love to death draws parallels between Sokolov’s novel and Blok’s Balaganchik, although there is a very long literary tradition that has developed this line (e.g., Eros and Thanatos; Catullus’s Odi et amo, I hate and I love). Read the original by Blok here.

intertextuality language translation theme
Orina

Orina, along with her variants, is the primary female character in the novel. In a sense, she is the only female figure in Between Dog and Wolf. As D.B. Johnson summarizes, the “promiscuous heroine Orina-Mariia is a train dispatcher, a princess in her dispatcher’s tower, who entertains her coworkers in her bed. Some of her orgiastic trysts take place near the train tracks to which her lovers tie her meddling husband Il’ia. Orina, in at least one time dimension, is killed by a train as she belatedly tries to save Il’ia who loses his leg” (“Twilight Cosmos” 647). Ilya is obsessed with this woman, and this passion “is the ultimate source of the woes that befall Il’ia, the itinerant grinder. It is his passion for the faithless slut Orina that brings about his misfortunes: the loss of his leg, his wandering life as a drunken grinder, and the grisly events that lead to his death” (643). Orina, alternatively called Maria, exists in the book also in another version, as ta dama, that dame, “a mysterious woman who appears along the river seeking Il’ia and, failing to find him, takes away a new lover each time […]. Her chance lovers return days later, sexually depleted and without interest in life. They usually die by their own hand” (645). In this figure (which embodies “virtually all female figures in the book,” D.B. Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 211), Sokolov merges two of his major literary themes: sex and death. Thus, Orina, Maria, that dame (ta dama, ta devochka, ta bobylka, ta babulya — all linked by the demonstrative “ta”), “Life Everlastin,” and death in general make up a unique polymorphic character. Smith notices that this female figure “does not appear at all in the verse. The episode of the sexual encounter between this figure and the sailors, which reoccurs obsessively in the prose, is correspondingly absent from the verse passages” (333). Olga Matich suggests the existence of a literary subtext for Sokolov’s novel: “Pilniak’s lesser known story Mother Earth (Mat’ syra zemlia 1927) about the violent confrontation between a naive young Bolshevik and an archaic Volga peasant community at the time of the Civil War. It is a kind of love story between the city-bred Bolshevik and the horse-tanner and young earth mother Arina, impaled by the Cossacks in one of the story’s many violence-ridden episodes. A variation on the Scythian juxtaposition of nature and culture, the story also depicts Arina’s maternal love for a fox cub, whom she tries to tame, thinking it is a wolf” (“Sasha Sokolov and His Literary Context” 312). The name Orina may also carry an echo of Pushkin’s famous nurse Arina Rodionovna (Toker 353). Mario Caramitti proposes three recurring hypostases of ta dama across Sokolov’s novels: a first hypostasis is that of a “mysterious woman carrying an obscure menace and/or sexual temptation”; a second hypostasis is that of an “apparently better defined and concrete woman being the object of desire for the main character”; and the third hypostasis is that of a “child-woman, often mentally retarded, often victim of violences, who touches upon a slightly more sublimated erotic sphere” (“Amore e morte” 114). Caramitti also adds that in the novel one of ta dama’s victims, before or after committing suicide, explicitly calls her “вечная жизнь” (Life Everlastin): “it is precisely in the coitus with eternity, in a region of oblivion that it is most difficult to place on this side or on the other side of the Lethe, that the male protagonist finds the widest surface of contact with this protean female entity of now vast symbolic implications” (118). Among Orina’s many lovers and among the men who take advantage of her, there is also Yakov, her son, who is in a way “re-enacting the role of the lame Oedipus” (Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). In chapter 14, Orina’s patronymic is said to be “Ignat’evna” (daughter of Ignatii): the name Ignatii possibly comes from the Latin “ignis” (fire) (R258/E190). Given that Orina is depicted here through her lust, such a patronymic seems apt. Her last name is said to be alternatively Neklina and Paklina (Spacklin, in translation): “You were called around the barracks Orina Neklina, and to whom do you belong now, to what kind of, let’s suppose, Spacklin, ah?” (R246/E169). On the border with Ukraine, close to Mariupol’ and to Chekhov’s hometown Taganrog, there is Rostov district named Neklinovsky. Paklia and paklina are regional terms indicating different things: a left-handed person, an unhandy and clumsy person, a bony hand, a piece of hemp or coarse fiber, messy hair. The terms паклен (paklen) and неклен (neklen) are named for the Tatar maple (note the slight differences in the spelling between the tree names and Orina’s surnames: Neklina, Paklina). As Sokolov explains, “Apparently, the author of the Notes and Ilya know or have heard about a man named Paklin. Ilya says that Arina’s last name was Neklina, probably after one of her men. And now, years later, Ilya assumes, she lives with someone else, whose last name suggests to him the tree’s other name” (personal communication, July 7, 2023).

intertextuality intratextuality character theme
cast dispersions

Cast aspersions.

unknown ladies

That is, sex workers. A reference to Blok’s “Unknown Lady.” Read the original and an English translation here.

That is, sex workers.

This term is used several times throughout the novel and is associated with Orina.

theme character intertextuality intratextuality
I will call this, like the scandals and thievery, Discords Beyond the Itil

explanatory

intertextuality religion bible
I’m registered with one, share a household with her, but I am burnin for another

Ilya admits being married, legally joined with a woman, but longing for another one (Orina).

character
That’s why the tall tales of crickets behind the stove are bothering llya. The moment I hear them—our outins and rides to suburban little towns with grasshoppers come to the surface

Sokolov explains: “In a normal country house there are crickets. They usually live behind the stove, where it is warmer. People love their crickets and listen to their songs with pleasure, it is believed that crickets bring happiness to the house. Ilya listens to crickets in the house of his female roommate, and their chirping reminds him of the chirping of grasshoppers, with which he associates country trips when he lived with Orina. Grasshoppers don’t live in big cities, but in small towns, why not?” (personal communication, August 21, 2023). Animal motif.

motif Russia explanatory
crickets

Animal motif.

motif
llya

Ilya here refers to himself in the third person. Ilya is Between Dog and Wolf’s protagonist and the author of what he calls the Zaitil’shchina, a long letter with epic traits (starting from its title) addressed to Inspector Pozhilykh in which he comments on the theft of his crutches (he has only one leg) and, more generally, describes life along the Volga River. Johnson defines Ilya’s letter as “semiliterate ramblings,” aptly suggesting the style and register the reader will encounter in the novel (“Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). However, this character expresses at the same time a highly poetic and imaginative gaze. Ilya frequently associates himself with the biblical prophet Elijah, a figure folklorically linked with thunderstorms and which in Slavic tradition acquired some of the characteristics of the pagan God of the sky and thunder, Perun. Ilya is closely related to other key characters of the novel: he describes his troubled relationship with Orina (alternatively called Maria and the Dame) with whom he has a son; in encountering Yakov (the focus of several chapters), he suggests the possibility of being his father. The Oedipal plot resulting from this triangle has been noted by scholars, such as Johnson, who writes that “the game warden Iakov lusts for his mother (reincarnate as a mentally defective girl) and kills his father-all without being aware of the identity of either” (“Twilight Cosmos” 644).

explanatory theme
Won’t you reveal who bangothumped all the mange out from the dog-master’s bitch?

explanatory
bangothumped

register/style
jackaloo

Ilya mistakes the animal (actually a dog) for a wolf. As Ostanin notes, in Egyptian mythology, Anubis, the god of the dead who would ferry the deceased to the underworld, takes the form of a jackal or a man with the head of a jackal. Animal motif.

motif intertextuality religion

As Ostanin notes, the expression “клочочки по закоулочкам” is a recurring phrase in the fairy tale “The Fox and the Hare” (89). Read it in the original here.

intertextuality
And I gave them my account of the battle

Again, Ilya describes his battle with the wolf (dog) on the frozen river.

explanatory
Gorodnishche

The main setting of the novel: a fictional town on the banks of the Volga River. Also called Gorodnishchi. Derived from the words for town (gorod) and beggar (nishchii). It is the “town of beggars.” Olga Matich writes: “If School for Fools was written against the background of youth prose, Sokolov’s next novel Between Dog and Wolf may be read as the author’s response to village prose, the literary rage of the seventies” (“Sasha Sokolov” 310). Vadim Kreid observes that Gorodnishche, a barracks village of beggars and thieves, resembles an “Anti-Kitezh” (Kitezh being the legendary, mythical city in Russian folklore that only the pure-hearted will have the chance to reach). In Gorodnishche, however, thieves rob beggars, while beggars beg thieves (“Zaitil’shchina” 213). According to Johnson, the living dwell Gorodnishche, while the dead reside on the other side of the river, in Bydogoshch (“Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 209). Johnson also mentions a statement by Sokolov himself: “Sokolov reports that the name is a blend of the dissolute eighteen-century town of Gorodnya described by A. N. Radishchev in his Journey from Petersburg to Moscow and a nearby town called Gorodishche. Thus the time layers of the sixteenth century, the eighteenth century, and a mythic present are all superimposed upon each other – a characteristic technique in the novel” (217).

character explanatory
Sindirela

Another variation on Ilya’s unusual last name, which is printed in more than ten different versions in the book. It carries allusions to Cinderella (see L. Toker’s essay, “Gamesman’s Sketches (Found in a Bottle),” CASS 21.3-4: 356). It is here spelled even closer to that of Cinderella. However, as Korovashko suggests, “Ilya Petrikevich becomes a kind of Cinderella ‘squared’: if the latter lost only his shoe, he lost both his leg and the crutches that compensate for its absence” (277).

explanatory music
To distant destination will soon depart the train, the cars will leave the station, the platform will remain. The station has a clock, the brick wall is all red, the kerchiefs a white flock, the eyes so deeply sad

Lyrics from Mikhail L’vovsky’s song “The train will leave for Tikhoretskaya.” Read the lyrics here. Listen to a recording by Vladimir Vysotsky here. It was made famous by the successful movie The Irony of Fate. Watch the film here. See Smith’s “Underground Songs” for more information and context on this style of music in the Soviet Union. Describing publisher Carl Proffer’s difficulties understanding Sokolov’s drafts of the novel, D. Barton Johnson writes: “Sokolov was surprised at this and later reactions: ‘It was my first clash with reality. I hadn’t even known [the thing] was complex. No idea. I thought I had written on the level that [Vladimir] Vysotskii writes song lyrics’ (DBJ interview June 20, 1983)” (“Background Notes” 339). Railroad theme.

theme intertextuality music
firebird

The mythical Firebird from Slavic folklore. Read the original here and an English translation here. In one version of the story, the Firebird transforms into a crow (as mentioned at the end of this sentence). Margaret Ziolkowski explains: “The bird resumes its fantastic form when Ivan returns safely home. Ivan’s father wonders what this transformation signifies, and the answer seems to be that the Firebird’s temporary metamorphosis into a dreary-looking crow is a symbolic consequence of Ivan’s betrayal by his brothers […] In Sokolov’s novel, many primarily sexual betrayals occur, but also a more wide-ranging metaphysical betrayal. The world portrayed in Between Dog and Wolf is marred by spiritual emptiness and pervasive cynicism, and the reference to the Firebird belies the loveliness of the landscape. The Firebird’s sad transformation is symbolically akin to the many images of physical and psychological maiming that occur in all three of Sokolov’s novels and point to the fractured and fragmented nature of existence” (414). Here, the Firebird is used metaphoric to refer to a girl and to the potential happiness she would bring (Ziolkowski 415). Animal motif.

folklore intertextuality motif
Zhmerinka

A city in central Ukraine.

location foreign
someone shamelessly carried off from the car his huntin boots

Similarly to how Ilya gets his crutches stolen.

explanatory
boots

D.B. Johnson has identified more than twenty different types of shoes across Sokolov’s three novels: “bashmaki, botforty, boty, botinki (polubotinki), cheboty, chizmy, chubury, galoshi (kaloshi), gety, ichigi, kedy, klogi, lapti, mokrostupy, obuvi (obuvki), sapogi, sandalii, tapochki (polutapochki), shlepantsy, shtiblety, tapti, tufli, valenki. The list may easily be extended with appurtenances such as socks, stockings, footcloths, gaiters, skates, crutches, and artificial legs” (“The Galoshes Manifesto” 156). Regarding Between Dog and Wolf, he notes that Ilya’s last name immediately evokes Cinderella’s vair slippers. Johnson observes that “the footwear motif is Sokolov’s tribute, both conscious and unconscious, to the tradition in Russian literature represented by his predecessors – Ivan Bunin and Valentin Kataev” (179). In an interview with A. and N. Voronel’, Sokolov calls Bunin, along with Gogol, his “contemporaries, collaborators along a chain, older masters” (Voroneli, “Ia khochu” 184). Shoe motif.

motif intertextuality
Or how in his youth a certain person lost her head gazin at him; she served at the N-junction, with a motley schlagbauman

This anecdote recalls Ilya’s account of Orina’s work at a railway station, as well as that of Yakov’s dealings with Maria, who also works the rails.

explanatory intratextuality
N

A convention of nineteenth-century literature to avoid naming a particular location by replacing it with “N.” For example, the “town of N.”

location explanatory
schlagbauman

German: slamming down + pole. A pole or bar used to control access to a space. As Boguslawski notes, the narrator puns on schlagbaum and Bauman, “referring to Nikolai Ernestovich Bauman, 1873–1905, a relatively insignificant Bolshevik revolutionary, later turned by the Soviet propaganda into a cult figure” (“Annotations” 251).

foreign explanatory
a cornet, paid zero attention

According to Ostanin, a reference to Nikolai Nekrasov’s 1846 poem “The Troika”: “Загляделся проезжий корнет” (90). Read the original poem here. Read an English translation here. This figure also appears in Note VI (R170/E36).

intertextuality intratextuality
cornet

In the pre-revolutionary Russian army, the first officer rank in the cavalry and border guard.

The smokin car will ask about my now, my past, I’ll tell a bunch of crap to shock and make them pout. What truly I gave up they don’t need to find out

Lyrics from Mikhail L’vovsky’s song “The train will leave for Tikhoretskaya.” Read the lyrics here. Listen to a recording by Vladimir Vysotsky here. See Smith’s “Underground Songs” for more information and context on this style of music in the Soviet Union. Railroad theme.

intertextuality music theme
havin wasted the entire century, he’s got the feelin that he blew off the most importantest bird of his fate, very likely not around Zhmerinka but on that motleyish switch, givin the gal the cold shoulder

The mythical Firebird from Slavic folklore. Read the original here and an English translation here. Margaret Ziolkowski writes: “Here the Firebird has becomes [sic] an explicit metaphor for an evanescent happiness. Moreover, while the folktale Firebird never changes into a person, in Sokolov’s novel the Firebird symbolically acquires a human identity. Thus the traveller did not recognize the real Firebird, who might actually have made his dreams come true, in the woman encountered years before” (415). Animal motif.

A sailor in striped shirt will open his poor heart, he’ll say that he is hurt and that his life is hard. He’ll reach his destination, won’t look back at the train, the cars will leave the station, the platform will remain

Lyrics from Mikhail L’vovsky’s song “The train will leave for Tikhoretskaya.” Read the lyrics here. Listen to a recording by Vladimir Vysotsky here. See Smith’s “Underground Songs” for more information and context on this style of music in the Soviet Union. Railroad theme.

intertextuality music theme
I sang and suffered: Oh, you swallow of mine, for whom did you leave me, havin taken the son and havin changed your and his last name, and where are you both right now—nobody knows

Throughout the novel, Ilya is associated with the hoopoe. In Ovid’s Metamorphoses Tereus is transformed into a hoopoe and searches for his missing family, calling out “where, where” in the bird’s famous song. Therefore, Ilya reenacts this plot as he seeks out Orina and their son, Yakov. Most importantly here, “Ilya closes the loop, so to speak, when he calls Orina ‘you swallow of mine,’ while bemoaning how she took his son from him. He is displaced, like Tereus, in his various transformations and peregrinations, pursuing his idealized family, but constantly mired by the imagery he uses and that is used to describe him” (Vergara, “Flap” 366). Animal-human motif.

intertextuality music
Don

location Russia
maple

Plant motif.

motif
Orina

Orina, along with her variants, is the primary female character in the novel. In a sense, she is the only female figure in Between Dog and Wolf. As D.B. Johnson summarizes, the “promiscuous heroine Orina-Mariia is a train dispatcher, a princess in her dispatcher’s tower, who entertains her coworkers in her bed. Some of her orgiastic trysts take place near the train tracks to which her lovers tie her meddling husband Il’ia. Orina, in at least one time dimension, is killed by a train as she belatedly tries to save Il’ia who loses his leg” (“Twilight Cosmos” 647). Ilya is obsessed with this woman, and this passion “is the ultimate source of the woes that befall Il’ia, the itinerant grinder. It is his passion for the faithless slut Orina that brings about his misfortunes: the loss of his leg, his wandering life as a drunken grinder, and the grisly events that lead to his death” (643). Orina, alternatively called Maria, exists in the book also in another version, as ta dama, that dame, “a mysterious woman who appears along the river seeking Il’ia and, failing to find him, takes away a new lover each time […]. Her chance lovers return days later, sexually depleted and without interest in life. They usually die by their own hand” (645). In this figure (which embodies “virtually all female figures in the book,” D.B. Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 211), Sokolov merges two of his major literary themes: sex and death. Thus, Orina, Maria, that dame (ta dama, ta devochka, ta bobylka, ta babulya — all linked by the demonstrative “ta”), “Life Everlastin,” and death in general make up a unique polymorphic character. Smith notices that this female figure “does not appear at all in the verse. The episode of the sexual encounter between this figure and the sailors, which reoccurs obsessively in the prose, is correspondingly absent from the verse passages” (333). Olga Matich suggests the existence of a literary subtext for Sokolov’s novel: “Pilniak’s lesser known story Mother Earth (Mat’ syra zemlia 1927) about the violent confrontation between a naive young Bolshevik and an archaic Volga peasant community at the time of the Civil War. It is a kind of love story between the city-bred Bolshevik and the horse-tanner and young earth mother Arina, impaled by the Cossacks in one of the story’s many violence-ridden episodes. A variation on the Scythian juxtaposition of nature and culture, the story also depicts Arina’s maternal love for a fox cub, whom she tries to tame, thinking it is a wolf” (“Sasha Sokolov and His Literary Context” 312). The name Orina may also carry an echo of Pushkin’s famous nurse Arina Rodionovna (Toker 353). Mario Caramitti proposes three recurring hypostases of ta dama across Sokolov’s novels: a first hypostasis is that of a “mysterious woman carrying an obscure menace and/or sexual temptation”; a second hypostasis is that of an “apparently better defined and concrete woman being the object of desire for the main character”; and the third hypostasis is that of a “child-woman, often mentally retarded, often victim of violences, who touches upon a slightly more sublimated erotic sphere” (“Amore e morte” 114). Caramitti also adds that in the novel one of ta dama’s victims, before or after committing suicide, explicitly calls her “вечная жизнь” (Life Everlastin): “it is precisely in the coitus with eternity, in a region of oblivion that it is most difficult to place on this side or on the other side of the Lethe, that the male protagonist finds the widest surface of contact with this protean female entity of now vast symbolic implications” (118). Among Orina’s many lovers and among the men who take advantage of her, there is also Yakov, her son, who is in a way “re-enacting the role of the lame Oedipus” (Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). In chapter 14, Orina’s patronymic is said to be “Ignat’evna” (daughter of Ignatii): the name Ignatii possibly comes from the Latin “ignis” (fire) (R258/E190). Given that Orina is depicted here through her lust, such a patronymic seems apt. Her last name is said to be alternatively Neklina and Paklina (Spacklin, in translation): “You were called around the barracks Orina Neklina, and to whom do you belong now, to what kind of, let’s suppose, Spacklin, ah?” (R246/E169). On the border with Ukraine, close to Mariupol’ and to Chekhov’s hometown Taganrog, there is Rostov district named Neklinovsky. Paklia and paklina are regional terms indicating different things: a left-handed person, an unhandy and clumsy person, a bony hand, a piece of hemp or coarse fiber, messy hair. The terms паклен (paklen) and неклен (neklen) are named for the Tatar maple (note the slight differences in the spelling between the tree names and Orina’s surnames: Neklina, Paklina). As Sokolov explains, “Apparently, the author of the Notes and Ilya know or have heard about a man named Paklin. Ilya says that Arina’s last name was Neklina, probably after one of her men. And now, years later, Ilya assumes, she lives with someone else, whose last name suggests to him the tree’s other name” (personal communication, July 7, 2023).

character theme intertextuality intratextuality
He seemed so unknown that one could erect a monument to him

He refers to the common monument (tomb) of the Unknown Soldier or, given the book’s context, Sailor (such as the one located in Odessa).

explanatory
Albatrosov

This name calls to mind two famous poetic “albatrosses”: Baudelaire’s (read it here) and Coleridge’s from The Rime of the Ancient Mariner (read it here). Addressing the latter subtext’s image of a bird wrapped around a sailor’s neck in penance, José Vergara writes, “Albatrosov is an embodiment of Ilya’s perceived betrayal by Orina, who it is said, sleeps with a number of sailors under the aforementioned overturned boat on the banks of the Volga, as well as guilt over his own actions. Ilya takes on his sorrow when he meets Albatrosov on a train after his separation from Orina. The avian-sailor thus serves to remind Ilya of the past he cannot escape. […] The anthropomorphized bird imagery, in this way, underscores Ilya’s lingering psychological trauma, both that which he himself caused and that which he received” (“Flap” 372). Animal-human motif. In a 2004 interview with Mario Caramitti, Sokolov comments on the suggestion of art predicting life in mysterious ways mentioning this specific character: “In the winter of 1978 I was living in Michigan and working on my second novel. One of the characters in the book, named Al’batrosov, has a background as a stoker on a ship. I was outlining the character by modeling him on my half-brother, a sailor, who was aboard a freighter at the time. Without thinking about the possible consequences, I made Albatrosov’s fate take a turn for the worse: an explosion in the engine room takes off his arm. When the book came out, I learned that in the same days that I was writing that episode my brother lost an arm to an accident. This is, I would say, the cruelest and most disconcerting example in my practice as a writer. But on the whole what I write often comes true. More often, unfortunately, than I would like, since I generally write about unpleasant things” (“Sokolov, il fabbro pellegrino della prosa russa” 12). The same concept is described by the author in his 1981 essay On Secret Tablets: “things described in fiction come true; fate suggests to the neglected in spirit solutions that it has already found. And it does not make any difference whether the master creates life myths or they create him: the text has been recorded in the same place, on secret tablets. And nothing else but fate will answer all the questions and decide what will remain – silence or the word. And, if necessary, it’ll rip out our sinful tongues” (7).

theme
Gypsy

In chapter 14 Ilya will suggest that his last name is actually of Gipsy origin.

intratextuality character
shroud

The shroud is typically white, so here, Ilya refers to the snow covering the “native expanses” (land) metaphorically. Clothing motif.

motif metaphor
wandrins are distant and constant

A possible allusion to the Wandering Jew, a figure mentioned in ch. 9 (“Agasfer”).

intertextuality intratextuality
Ilya

Ilya here refers to himself in the third person. Ilya is Between Dog and Wolf’s protagonist and the author of what he calls the Zaitil’shchina, a long letter with epic traits (starting from its title) addressed to Inspector Pozhilykh in which he comments on the theft of his crutches (he has only one leg) and, more generally, describes life along the Volga River. Johnson defines Ilya’s letter as “semiliterate ramblings,” aptly suggesting the style and register the reader will encounter in the novel (“Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). However, this character expresses at the same time a highly poetic and imaginative gaze. Ilya frequently associates himself with the biblical prophet Elijah, a figure folklorically linked with thunderstorms and which in Slavic tradition acquired some of the characteristics of the pagan God of the sky and thunder, Perun. Ilya is closely related to other key characters of the novel: he describes his troubled relationship with Orina (alternatively called Maria and the Dame) with whom he has a son; in encountering Yakov (the focus of several chapters), he suggests the possibility of being his father. The Oedipal plot resulting from this triangle has been noted by scholars, such as Johnson, who writes that “the game warden Iakov lusts for his mother (reincarnate as a mentally defective girl) and kills his father-all without being aware of the identity of either” (“Twilight Cosmos” 644).

Quotation from Matthew 16:17.

explanatory intertextuality
from the Siberian mines

An allusion to Alexander Pushkin’s 1827 poem “Deep in Siberia’s Mines…” written to commemorate the experiences of his Decembrist friends and comrades. Read the original and English translations here.

intertextuality
bop

Dancing. This word is crucial to Sokolov’s art. Chorea — a movement disorder belonging to the dyskinesias group of neurological disorders. Its name comes from the Ancient Greek “χορεία” and was used to described the movements of those inflicted by the disease. Sokolov’s first novel, A School for Fools, is dedicated to Vita Pliaskina, which refers to Sydenham’s chorea (also known as “St. Vitus’s dance, пляска святого Вита in Russian). Watch a video here. Referred to several times in the novel (R171, 191, 205, 214, 215/E37, 74, 97, 113, 115).

intertextuality
To the accompaniment of squeakin wheel flanges, a thoughtful invalidual will mill over all kinds of stuff durin a long trip from an infirmary to the Tower Junction; he will mill it over—and there will be flour

From the expression “Всё перемелется — мука будет” (Everything will get milled over; there will be flour). An expression of the milling theme in the novel. Sokolov will play with this expression and the difference between му́ка (torment) and мукá (flour) several times.

phraseologism intertextuality theme language
invalidual

The word used in the original, “individ,” is literary in Russian, and thus in this context it sounds unnaturally; the actual word Ilya possibly means to use is “invalid.” Boguslawski keeps this linguistic twist.

intertextuality intratextuality self-reference
boots

D.B. Johnson has identified more than twenty different types of shoes across Sokolov’s three novels: “bashmaki, botforty, boty, botinki (polubotinki), cheboty, chizmy, chubury, galoshi (kaloshi), gety, ichigi, kedy, klogi, lapti, mokrostupy, obuvi (obuvki), sapogi, sandalii, tapochki (polutapochki), shlepantsy, shtiblety, tapti, tufli, valenki. The list may easily be extended with appurtenances such as socks, stockings, footcloths, gaiters, skates, crutches, and artificial legs” (“The Galoshes Manifesto” 156). Regarding Between Dog and Wolf, he notes that Ilya’s last name immediately evokes Cinderella’s vair slippers. Johnson observes that “the footwear motif is Sokolov’s tribute, both conscious and unconscious, to the tradition in Russian literature represented by his predecessors – Ivan Bunin and Valentin Kataev” (179). In an interview with A. and N. Voronel’, Sokolov calls Bunin, along with Gogol, his “contemporaries, collaborators along a chain, older masters” (Voroneli, “Ia khochu” 184). Shoe motif.

explanatory music
Эх, шерочка, да ты машерочка, косолапочка, престарелочка.

Alliteration; internal rhyme.

Аллитерация и внутренняя рифма.

sound stylistic device
шерочка, да ты машерочка

Set expression: шерочка с машерочкой (joined at the hip, bosom buddies).

phraseologism
косолапочка

Having clubfoot. We should here remember Sophocle’s Oedipus, who had a swollen foot. Several authors have underlined the parallels existing between Sokolov’s novel(s) and the story of Oedipus. Olga Matich, for example, writes: “Written in a language that is self-consciously apolitical and un-Soviet, it is a surreal tale of violence and death based on the reenactment of the Oedipus myth” (“Sasha Sokolov’s Palisandriia” 416). D.B. Johnson also notes: “Sokolov’s three novels are linked by an evolving Oedipal theme. The Oedipal image is latent in School for Fools. The boy, who hates his prosecutor father, apparently does not understand why his ‘kindly, patient’ mother disappears upstairs with the accordion teacher during his lessons. That he is unconsciously jealous of his mother’s infidelity is suggested by the skirly-squeaking of the stair- case and the squealing of his accordion. Oedipal incest is somewhat more overt in Dog and Wolf thanks to a complex set of superimposed figures from different time dimensions: the game warden Iakov lusts for his mother (reincarnate as a mentally defective girl) and kills his father-all without being aware of the iden- tity of either. The incest theme comes to the fore in Palisandr. The hero’s memory is haunted by incestuous sexual violence. In an incarnation centuries before, Palisandr, a motherless orphan, had been brutally corrupted by his maternal aunt, Majorette, his father’s mistress. This experience has been stamped into his sexual memory and is relived in variant form in subsequent incarnations. Incest is the Original Sin that colors his sexual behavior in all possible pasts, presents, and futures” (“Sasha Sokolov’s Twilight Cosmos” 644). However, Johnson also adds that in a conversation with Sokolov, the author admitted that “although he did not initially have the Oedipus parallel in mind, it struck him during and after the writing” (“The Galoshes” 165).

intertextuality self-reference
Горе тебе, Городнище

Alliteration (gor).

Аллитерация (гор).

sound stylistic device
Горе тебе, Городнище большое, мощнеющий град

Intertextual reference to the Book of Revelation 18:10. Ostanin also draws a parallel to Ivan Bunin’s 1916 “The Horse of Afina-Pallada” (85). Read the poem here.

intertextuality religion bible
Городнище

The main setting of the novel: a fictional town on the banks of the Volga River. Also called Gorodnishchi. Derived from the words for town (gorod) and beggar (nishchii). It is the “town of beggars.” Olga Matich writes: “If School for Fools was written against the background of youth prose, Sokolov’s next novel Between Dog and Wolf may be read as the author’s response to village prose, the literary rage of the seventies” (“Sasha Sokolov” 310). Vadim Kreid observes that Gorodnishche, a barracks village of beggars and thieves, resembles an “Anti-Kitezh” (Kitezh being the legendary, mythical city in Russian folklore that only the pure-hearted will have the chance to reach). In Gorodnishche, however, thieves rob beggars, while beggars beg thieves (“Zaitil’shchina” 213). According to Johnson, the living dwell Gorodnishche, while the dead reside on the other side of the river, in Bydogoshch (“Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 209). Johnson also mentions a statement by Sokolov himself: “Sokolov reports that the name is a blend of the dissolute eighteen-century town of Gorodnya described by A. N. Radishchev in his Journey from Petersburg to Moscow and a nearby town called Gorodishche. Thus the time layers of the sixteenth century, the eighteenth century, and a mythic present are all superimposed upon each other – a characteristic technique in the novel” (217).

location setting folklore
Городнище большое, мощнеющий

Alliteration (shch/sh).

Аллитерация (щ/ш).

sound stylistic device
град

Archaism: city.

archaism
пляски

Dancing. This word is crucial to Sokolov’s art. Chorea — a movement disorder belonging to the dyskinesias group of neurological disorders. Its name comes from the Ancient Greek “χορεία” and was used to described the movements of those inflicted by the disease. Sokolov’s first novel, A School for Fools, is dedicated to Vita Pliaskina, which refers to Sydenham’s chorea (also known as “St. Vitus’s dance, пляска святого Вита in Russian). Watch a video here. Referred to several times in the novel (R171, 191, 205, 214, 215/E37, 74, 97, 113, 115).

intratextuality self-reference intertextuality
меня мелькнуло немножечко

Alliteration.

Аллитерация.

sound stylistic device
есть-пошла

An archaic verbal form from Old Church Slavonic. A reference to Nestor’s Primary Chronicle and its opening lines: “whence the Russian land?” Read the original in OCS here and in Russian here and an English translation here.

intertextuality Russia archaism
смутная

Ilya draws a parallel between his account and the Time of Troubles (Смутноте время, 1598-1613), the period of political and social turmoil that followed the death of Fyodor I, the last of the Rurik dynasty.

time Russia
Заитильщина

The title of Ilya’s chapters derives from the Tatar name of the Volga river (Itil’), and recalls the Zadonshchina, an epic literary text (dated late 14th century) about the Battle of Kulikovo of 1380 (its title derives from the river Don). As “the Zadonshchina shows the humanity of the Tatar troops and expresses genuine sympathy for a grief the Russian and Tatar alike could understand” (Halperin, *The Golden Horde *109), the Zaitil’shchina describes the diverse human universe by the Volga (Zavol’zhe), or Wolf river (Zavol’che) as it is called by paronomastic association between the terms Volga and “volk” (wolf). Andrei Zorin describes the setting of the novel in these terms: “in the second novel, the directly named Zaitil’shchina, or Zavolzh’e, serves only as a symbol for a lost corner of the earth. The specific topographical realities here are deliberately scarce, and the historical ones are so thoroughly mixed up that it is absolutely impossible to reconcile the events described with any particular part of our century. And this desire of the writer for the ultimate universalization of time and space in his novel finds its most vivid expression in the role played in his artistic world by the painting of Pieter Bruegel the Elder” (“Nasylaiushchii veter” 252); “The theme of physical damage in the novel becomes another embodiment of the Zaitil’shchina, a land where nothing is being built, produced, and only occasionally repaired, and more often it decays, becomes unusable, breaks and steals” (“Nasylaiushchii veter” 253). Vadim Kreid, titling his article “Zaitil’shchina,” describes the “bezvremen’e” (the absence of time) as the “неизлечимая болезнь Заитильского бытия” (incurable illness of life in Zavol’zhe), while he also points out a specific “agnosticism” typical of this fictional world, based on “carelessness, inevitability of desolation, and nothingness (non-existence) as redemption” (беспечность, неизбежность опустошения и небытие как избавление) (216-217).

нелады

Аллитерация (с, б).

sound stylistic device
сбеленилась

Colloquial: to go wild, lose one’s cool, froth at the mouth.

register/style
тронулась

Colloquial: to go nuts.

register/style
дамы той

Orina, along with her variants, is the primary female character in the novel. In a sense, she is the only female figure in Between Dog and Wolf. As D.B. Johnson summarizes, the “promiscuous heroine Orina-Mariia is a train dispatcher, a princess in her dispatcher’s tower, who entertains her coworkers in her bed. Some of her orgiastic trysts take place near the train tracks to which her lovers tie her meddling husband Il’ia. Orina, in at least one time dimension, is killed by a train as she belatedly tries to save Il’ia who loses his leg” (“Twilight Cosmos” 647). Ilya is obsessed with this woman, and this passion “is the ultimate source of the woes that befall Il’ia, the itinerant grinder. It is his passion for the faithless slut Orina that brings about his misfortunes: the loss of his leg, his wandering life as a drunken grinder, and the grisly events that lead to his death” (643). Orina, alternatively called Maria, exists in the book also in another version, as ta dama, that dame, “a mysterious woman who appears along the river seeking Il’ia and, failing to find him, takes away a new lover each time […]. Her chance lovers return days later, sexually depleted and without interest in life. They usually die by their own hand” (645). In this figure (which embodies “virtually all female figures in the book,” D.B. Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 211), Sokolov merges two of his major literary themes: sex and death. Thus, Orina, Maria, that dame (ta dama, ta devochka, ta bobylka, ta babulya — all linked by the demonstrative “ta”), “Life Everlastin,” and death in general make up a unique polymorphic character. Smith notices that this female figure “does not appear at all in the verse. The episode of the sexual encounter between this figure and the sailors, which reoccurs obsessively in the prose, is correspondingly absent from the verse passages” (333). Olga Matich suggests the existence of a literary subtext for Sokolov’s novel: “Pilniak’s lesser known story Mother Earth (Mat’ syra zemlia 1927) about the violent confrontation between a naive young Bolshevik and an archaic Volga peasant community at the time of the Civil War. It is a kind of love story between the city-bred Bolshevik and the horse-tanner and young earth mother Arina, impaled by the Cossacks in one of the story’s many violence-ridden episodes. A variation on the Scythian juxtaposition of nature and culture, the story also depicts Arina’s maternal love for a fox cub, whom she tries to tame, thinking it is a wolf” (“Sasha Sokolov and His Literary Context” 312). The name Orina may also carry an echo of Pushkin’s famous nurse Arina Rodionovna (Toker 353). Mario Caramitti proposes three recurring hypostases of ta dama across Sokolov’s novels: a first hypostasis is that of a “mysterious woman carrying an obscure menace and/or sexual temptation”; a second hypostasis is that of an “apparently better defined and concrete woman being the object of desire for the main character”; and the third hypostasis is that of a “child-woman, often mentally retarded, often victim of violences, who touches upon a slightly more sublimated erotic sphere” (“Amore e morte” 114). Caramitti also adds that in the novel one of ta dama’s victims, before or after committing suicide, explicitly calls her “вечная жизнь” (Life Everlastin): “it is precisely in the coitus with eternity, in a region of oblivion that it is most difficult to place on this side or on the other side of the Lethe, that the male protagonist finds the widest surface of contact with this protean female entity of now vast symbolic implications” (118). Among Orina’s many lovers and among the men who take advantage of her, there is also Yakov, her son, who is in a way “re-enacting the role of the lame Oedipus” (Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). In chapter 14, Orina’s patronymic is said to be “Ignat’evna” (daughter of Ignatii): the name Ignatii possibly comes from the Latin “ignis” (fire) (R258/E190). Given that Orina is depicted here through her lust, such a patronymic seems apt. Her last name is said to be alternatively Neklina and Paklina (Spacklin, in translation): “You were called around the barracks Orina Neklina, and to whom do you belong now, to what kind of, let’s suppose, Spacklin, ah?” (R246/E169). On the border with Ukraine, close to Mariupol’ and to Chekhov’s hometown Taganrog, there is Rostov district named Neklinovsky. Paklia and paklina are regional terms indicating different things: a left-handed person, an unhandy and clumsy person, a bony hand, a piece of hemp or coarse fiber, messy hair. The terms паклен and неклен are named for the Tatar maple (note the slight differences in the spelling between the tree names and Orina’s surnames: Неклина, Паклина). As Sokolov explains, “Apparently, the author of the Notes and Ilya know or have heard about a man named Paklin. Ilya says that Arina’s last name was Neklina, probably after one of her men. And now, years later, Ilya assumes, she lives with someone else, whose last name suggests to him the tree’s other name” (personal communication, July 7, 2023).

character intertextuality intratextuality theme
карасики

Fish belonging to the Carassius genus and Cyprinidae family. Mentioned in chapters 1 (R157/E15) and 8 (R210/E106). Animal motif.

Рыба из семейства Карповых, род Караси. Изображено ниже:

Мотив животных. Упоминается в главах 1 (R157/E15) и 8 (R210/E106). А. Богуславский замечает: “Соколов усиляет художественное воздействие этих двух описаний путем соединения визуальных образов с мастерски использованным лексическим материалом. Несложно заметить легкие модуляции фраз, описывающих карасей, выполненные путем синонимичных замещений прищучился – пригляделся и дремали – кемарили, а также замена здесь где на тут у нас и ерши эти самые на мне взбрело вдруг” (Boguslawski, “How Sokolov’s” 215).

sound stylistic device
напропалую

Colloquial: hobnob, without thinking of the consequences. The men who disappear with the Dame for three days return and soon end their lives. Alexander Boguslawski writes: “Hence the sexual act [in Sokolov’s novel] is not only a happy union, but a bitter struggle; a fleeting moment of bliss and ecstasy ultimately ends in misery and suffering. Perhaps these thoughts may be explained as a distant reflection of the Freudian conflict between life instinct—Eros and death instinct—Thanatos (or even a merger between sex drive and death drive)” (“Death” 239–240). As D. Barton Johnson notes, “sexual obsession is the ultimate source of the woes that befall Il’ia” (“Sasha Sokolov’s Twilight Cosmos” 643).

register/style
Гурию

Gury is one of the hunters living by the river. His death is described in detail in chapter 14: during an ice race, “a few verstas before the turn, Gury began gainin and the whipper-in fallin behind, but Gury aimed slightly more to the right than he should and fell into a polynya, an ice hole in the area of the fairway. […] he plopped in and right away got sucked under the ice.” Since his body cannot be found until spring, his funeral is organized “without his factual presence” (R260/E196). This episode is already briefly alluded to in chapter 1: “He was the one that adored scrapin and rollin over the slick on his sharps, which additionally resulted in us losin a client, and the undertakers, in contrast, findin one” (R150/E3).

explanatory intratextuality character
Гурию, Федору, Калуге

The men who have died after their meetings with the Dame.

character explanatory
Федору

Pyotr/Fyodor/Yegor. Pyotr, “one smart aleck from Sloboda” (R173/E43), is Pavel’s uncle and is sent by his nephew in Gorodnishche to find yeast (when the story is retold in chapter 14, it is the uncle asking Pavel to get yeast). He is alternatively called Fyodor and Yegor: the choice seems to be guided by the presence of the vowels “e/ë” and “o.” The name Pyotr, from Greek, means “stone.” The apostle Peter (Simon Peter), in origin a fisherman, is considered the first Christian Pope. Peter denied Jesus three times during the events of the crucifixion, as Jesus had predicted (see Matthew 26:69–75). Fyodor (Theodore) means “God’s gift.” The name Egor is a variation of the name Georgy (George), from the Greek “farmer.” He was immortalized as a saint through the legend of the Dragon (Saint George the Dragon-slayer). In chapter 10 this character is challenged to hang himself, which results in his suicide.

character foreign intratextuality religion
Федору

The hunters tease and dare Yegor/Fyodor/Pyotr to hang himself after his time with the Dame (R222/E127–128).

character explanatory intratextuality
Калуге

In chapter 10, after returning from his time with the Dame, Kaluga eats belladonna berries and dies (R225/E131–132).

intratextuality character explanatory
Карабану В.

Vasily Karaban appears as the messenger who brings news of the phenomenon of Orina in the form of Everlastin’ Life or that Dame to the Volga community in which the novel is set. He is her first victim and, while he remains alive, he has shriveled up. His occupation, as Sokolov confirms, is unclear (personal communication, July 7, 2023). The name Karaban is of Turkic origin and can either be a surname or a nickname, a shortened version of Karabanov. It means “black mole” from “kara” (black) and “ban” (mole, birthmark). According to Turkic folklore, a black mole is a sign of happiness. Therefore, in the context of Between Dog and Wolf, it may be an ironic marker given Karaban’s fate (“Proiskhozhdenie familii Karabanova”). First appears at the end of chapter 10, which this chapter continues, of course (R225–226/E132–133).

character intratextuality foreign folklore
В

Vasily. Named in chapter 14 (R261/E197).

character
першит

Colloquial: to have a tickle in one’s throat, have an itchy throat, clear one’s throat.

register/style
Горе, горе

Emphatic repetition.

Эмфатический повтор.

rhythm
Горе, горе тебе, Городнище

Intertextual reference to the Book of Revelation 18:10. Ostanin also draws a parallel to Ivan Bunin’s 1916 “The Horse of Afina-Pallada” (85). Read the poem here.

intertextuality religion bible
Городнище

The main setting of the novel: a fictional town on the banks of the Volga River. Also called Gorodnishchi. Derived from the words for town (gorod) and beggar (nishchii). It is the “town of beggars.” Olga Matich writes: “If School for Fools was written against the background of youth prose, Sokolov’s next novel Between Dog and Wolf may be read as the author’s response to village prose, the literary rage of the seventies” (“Sasha Sokolov” 310). Vadim Kreid observes that Gorodnishche, a barracks village of beggars and thieves, resembles an “Anti-Kitezh” (Kitezh being the legendary, mythical city in Russian folklore that only the pure-hearted will have the chance to reach). In Gorodnishche, however, thieves rob beggars, while beggars beg thieves (“Zaitil’shchina” 213). According to Johnson, the living dwell Gorodnishche, while the dead reside on the other side of the river, in Bydogoshch (“Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 209). Johnson also mentions a statement by Sokolov himself: “Sokolov reports that the name is a blend of the dissolute eighteen-century town of Gorodnya described by A. N. Radishchev in his Journey from Petersburg to Moscow and a nearby town called Gorodishche. Thus the time layers of the sixteenth century, the eighteenth century, and a mythic present are all superimposed upon each other – a characteristic technique in the novel” (217).

location intertextuality setting folklore theme
и пустое, и ложное

A reference to Lamentations 2:14.

explanatory

Unusual (and mockingly foreign) word. It may derive from the word “kubar’”, informally used by students of the naval academy to define a ship cabin.

foreign location neologism
индивид

The word “individ” is bookish in Russian, and thus in this context it sounds unnaturally; as elsewhere in the novel, the actual word Ilya possibly means is “invalid.”

register/style
во свои круги

A variation of a popular catchphrase (“na krugi svoia”), derived from the Bible, Ecclesiastes 1:6. The catchphrase is used to mean the return of something or someone to their usual place, to their original position, and it suggests that there is nothing fundamentally new, as everything repeats itself.

rhythm

A reference to Mark 7:1–8, which describes Jesus’ encounter with the Pharisees who do not wash their hands before eating.

religion bible intertextuality
фарисейничая

Pharisees — a school of strict Jewish thought. Being common citizens, they contrasted the sacerdotal aristocracy, yet distinguished themselves from the uneducated masses (hence probably their name, meaning “separate”). The Pharisaic system was based on the oral teaching and interpretation of the Holy Scriptures; in the end, however, rather than a system of religious beliefs, it was a complex of life norms. Worship, previously almost exclusively confined to the priestly circle, became part of the family and individual everyday life. We know more about this school thanks to the works of Flavius Josephus (a 1st-century Roman-Jewish historian), a name mentioned by Sokolov in his Triptych (2011).

A Russian cabbage soup.

Russia
Щи не лаптем хлебаем

Set expression (without the negation; “shchi laptem khlebat’”): to live poorly.

phraseologism
лаптем

Bast shoes. D.B. Johnson has identified more than twenty different types of shoes across Sokolov’s three novels: “bashmaki, botforty, boty, botinki (polubotinki), cheboty, chizmy, chubury, galoshi (kaloshi), gety, ichigi, kedy, klogi, lapti, mokrostupy, obuvi (obuvki), sapogi, sandalii, tapochki (polutapochki), shlepantsy, shtiblety, tapti, tufli, valenki. The list may easily be extended with appurtenances such as socks, stockings, footcloths, gaiters, skates, crutches, and artificial legs” (“The Galoshes Manifesto” 156). Regarding Between Dog and Wolf, he notes that Ilya’s last name immediately evokes Cinderella’s vair slippers. Johnson observes that “the footwear motif is Sokolov’s tribute, both conscious and unconscious, to the tradition in Russian literature represented by his predecessors – Ivan Bunin and Valentin Kataev” (179). In an interview with A. and N. Voronel’, Sokolov calls Bunin, along with Gogol, his “contemporaries, collaborators along a chain, older masters” (Voroneli, “Ia khochu” 184). Shoe motif.

острым ногу набуть

To put on ice-skates. D.B. Johnson has identified more than twenty different types of shoes across Sokolov’s three novels: “bashmaki, botforty, boty, botinki (polubotinki), cheboty, chizmy, chubury, galoshi (kaloshi), gety, ichigi, kedy, klogi, lapti, mokrostupy, obuvi (obuvki), sapogi, sandalii, tapochki (polutapochki), shlepantsy, shtiblety, tapti, tufli, valenki. The list may easily be extended with appurtenances such as socks, stockings, footcloths, gaiters, skates, crutches, and artificial legs” (“The Galoshes Manifesto” 156). Regarding Between Dog and Wolf, he notes that Ilya’s last name immediately evokes Cinderella’s vair slippers. Johnson observes that “the footwear motif is Sokolov’s tribute, both conscious and unconscious, to the tradition in Russian literature represented by his predecessors – Ivan Bunin and Valentin Kataev” (179). In an interview with A. and N. Voronel’, Sokolov calls Bunin, along with Gogol, his “contemporaries, collaborators along a chain, older masters” (Voroneli, “Ia khochu” 184). Shoe motif.

explanatory motif
набуть

Dialectal: to put on (shoes).

register/style
Грустновато тем не менее между собакой на просторе родимых рек, хныкать вас подмывает, как того побирошу в четверть четвертого. Хмарь, ни кожа ни рожа, ни тень ни свет, ни в Городнище, ни в Быгодоще: взвинтил я темп

Natalya Fedotova and Daniil Osipov write: “The idea of the intersection of the spaces of being and non-being, perhaps only during twilight, is conveyed in this fragment at the syntactic level by the use of double negatives, and at the lexical and phraseological level through the verbal play with paremias that go back to the tradition of the fairy tale and express the concept of “no kind”, “incomprehensible”, “nondescript”, “indefinite”, “being in between” (neither fish nor meat; neither the light nor the dawn, etc.)” (64).

A possible allusion to Andrei Bely’s 1907 poem “I.” Read the original here.

As Ostanin notes, this pairing can be seen as a contrast between the living (the city of beggars) and the dead (city of the cemetery).

explanatory theme

Alliteration (niv, g, d, shch).

Аллитерация (нив, г, д, щ).

sound stylistic device
Городнище

The main setting of the novel: a fictional town on the banks of the Volga River. Also called Gorodnishchi. Derived from the words for town (gorod) and beggar (nishchii). It is the “town of beggars.” Olga Matich writes: “If School for Fools was written against the background of youth prose, Sokolov’s next novel Between Dog and Wolf may be read as the author’s response to village prose, the literary rage of the seventies” (“Sasha Sokolov” 310). Vadim Kreid observes that Gorodnishche, a barracks village of beggars and thieves, resembles an “Anti-Kitezh” (Kitezh being the legendary, mythical city in Russian folklore that only the pure-hearted will have the chance to reach). In Gorodnishche, however, thieves rob beggars, while beggars beg thieves (“Zaitil’shchina” 213). According to Johnson, the living dwell Gorodnishche, while the dead reside on the other side of the river, in Bydogoshch (“Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 209). Johnson also mentions a statement by Sokolov himself: “Sokolov reports that the name is a blend of the dissolute eighteen-century town of Gorodnya described by A. N. Radishchev in his Journey from Petersburg to Moscow and a nearby town called Gorodishche. Thus the time layers of the sixteenth century, the eighteenth century, and a mythic present are all superimposed upon each other – a characteristic technique in the novel” (217).

location theme setting intertextuality folklore
Быгодоще

As Sokolov explains, there is no relation between this location and the Polish town of Bydgoszcz (personal communication, June 7, 2023). It is rather a misspelling of the village (and lake) of Vidogoshch by the Volga River, near Tver’. D.B. Johnson suggests that, while the living dwell in Gorodnishche, Bydogoshch is home for the dead (“Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 209).

motif
Аладдин Рахматуллин

Mentioned four times in the novel with different surnames (R153/E7, R199/E89, R242/E161, R278/E225). The name of Arabic origin Aladdin (Al al-Din) means “nobility of faith” and was popularized by the success of One Thousand and One Nights, before the 1992 homonymous Disney movie. Here it is used to suggest the Tatar origin of the character (directly indicated in Note XIV). His last name is mentioned alternatively as Batrutdinov and Rakhmatullin: the first derives from the Arabic name Batrutdin which means “full moon of the faith”; the second is a Tatar or Bashkir last name, derived from the name Rahmatullah, “mercy of God.”

character intratextuality intertextuality religion

Reference to the song “Barynia-rechka” (Lady River), from the Soviet movie “Inzhener Promchatov” (1972). Listen to it here.

intertextuality
лампаду

Poetic: lamp, candle. Typically used in churches as lights before an icon. The term is derived from the name given to Hecate’s companions in Greek mythology. According to various stories, they lead the goddess of witchcraft’s way with lanterns (or other goddesses) and may lead humans to madness or death. The lamp is likely recalled here by the reference to Aladdin.

intertextuality intratextuality music Russia
И тут волка я усмотрел за сувоями

The central event of the novel: the moment when Ilya mistakes one of Yakov’s dogs for a wolf while skating home at twilight. Between dog and wolf.

theme explanatory
волка

The creature whom Ilya mistakes for a wolf is actually one of Yakov’s dogs. Between dog and wolf. The wolf has a long history of mythological and symbolic depictions, many of which are operative in Between Dog and Wolf: “Many of the early associations of the wolf as paradoxical: a murderous beast of prey, the natural symbol of night and winter, and even of death itself, its fierceness and swift movement also caused it to be identified with the sun, the life-giver, and with life” (Rowland, Animals 161). For more on this history, see Rowland, Animals 161–167. Animal motif.

theme motif explanatory

Dialectical: snowdrift.

register/style

explanatory

Literary/dated: here and there, back and forth.

register/style
Лафа

Dated/colloquial: benefit, luck.

register/style
Погибели

Foma Pogibel’ is one of the two oarsmen who carry people (dead or alive) across the river (a variation of the Charon Greek myth). The other oarsman is Eryoma (diminutive of Eremei, Jeremiah). However, in Note XXXI the oarsman is called Pavel, just like the character who sends his uncle Pyotr to get yeast in Gorodnishche. As underlined by one of the epigraphs in Sokolov’s first novel, A School for Fools, the biblical name of Pavel is somehow interchangeable: “Saul, who is called Paul” (see Acts 13:9–10). As for Foma, he carries a biblical name, too (Thomas), whose Aramaic origin suggests the idea of the “twin.” This apostle is famous as “Doubting Thomas” due to his denial of the resurrection of Jesus, according to the Gospel of John (see John 20:24–31). In the Orthodox tradition, the Sunday following Easter is called “Thomas Sunday”: the day when Christ appeared to his disciples; it took seeing Jesus’ body for Thomas to name him “My Lord and my God.”

Reference to the “wolf, goat, and cabbage puzzle,” which dates back to at least the ninth century and is popular in many cultures. Read it here. Mentioned in chapter 4 (R182/E58).

sound

Low: ration, portion of food.

register/style
гражданин

Sokolov avoids using the most common Soviet appellative “tovarishch” opting for a rather general, but still evocative word (think of Nikolay Nekrasov’s “Poet i grazhdanin,” Poet and Citizen, 1856). This choice is also related to the epistolary genre Ilya is trying to reproduce and to the fact that his world is the “old” one rather than the Soviet one. Richard Borden claims that “Between Dog and Wolf violate[s] specifically Soviet and Russian taboos in its language and its portrayal of Homo Sovieticus” (“Toward” 328).

language
Пожилых

An unusual surname that does not permit standard declination. It literally means Elderly. Ostanin suggests a connection to Boris Pasternak’s novel Doctor Zhivago by means of the root “zhiv” (to live) (10). Read the original here. Likewise, he notes that Alexander Pushkin considered including a story entitled “Notes of an Elderly Person” in his cycle of short stories, The Tales of Belkin. Read the original here and an English translation here. As Martina Napolitano observes, “Pozhilykh, Ilya’s addressee, is once ‘transfigured’ into an alleged Resurrection painting whose title plays on the ambiguity of his last name – Voskresenie Pozhilykh, The Resurrection of the Elderly. Ilya indeed concludes his letter wishing Pozhilykh “a happy resurrection”: this is his final message, his “good news.” It literally is his Gospel, from the Greek εὐαγγέλιον (good news); in the original, Ilya here distorts the canonical blagaia vest’ in ‘blagoe izvestie’” (“Studyin” 286).

Literary: individual. In this context, the word in Russian sounds unnaturally; the actual word Ilya possibly meant to use is “invalid.”

register/style language

Colloquial: mess, scrape. Also: bookbinding. Thus, this section operates on a metatextual level to comment on the difficulty of putting together a narrative.

register/style self-reference
на лезвиé

Ilya is missing a leg, thus he balances carefully on a single blade.

explanatory
лезвиé

Another sign of Ilya’s illiteracy (the accent should be on the first syllable).

register/style
ледовых побоищ

Reference to the medieval “Battle on the Ice” (5 April 1242), which was fought on the frozen Lake Peipus (today on the border between Estonia and Russia) between the Republic of Novgorod and Vladimir-Suzdal (led by Prince Alexander Nevsky), and the forces of the Livonian Order and Bishopric of Dorpat (today, Tartu). The outcome of battle determined whether Western Catholicism or Eastern Orthodox Christianity would dominate in the region. The latter prevailed. The event was (inaccurately) portrayed in Sergei Eisenstein’s movie Alexander Nevsky (1938).

intertextuality Russia
обрубки

A reference to the various men with missing limbs in the region. This detail of the novel is a product the violence described here by Ilya, but it is also part of the realia of the post-war setting.

Ice skating.

explanatory
слово за слово

Set expression: little by little. Again, as with “переплетах” (scrape + bookbinding), Ilya’s words (word by word) emphasize the metatextual quality of the narrative here.

phraseologism self-reference
протезом

A reference to the various men with missing limbs in the region. This detail of the novel is a product of the violence described here by Ilya, but it is also part of the realia of the post-war setting. While Olga Matich argues that Between Dog and Wolf “eschews recent history completely,” Sokolov in fact encodes these conditions of mid-century Soviet life into the novel (“Sasha Sokolov’s” 416). In an interview, Sokolov once said: “I see that belles-lettres become less and less popular, gives way to history. Solzhenitsyn understands this and decided that historical form interests the reader more, and therefore, he switched, he moved away entirely from belles-lettres, from the novel, he moved on to something new. But I don’t love history. I don’t believe in it. I don’t believe any research, any archives. All of that, in my opinion, is conjecture, thought up. But that’s not even the point. History simply doesn’t interest me. I don’t believe that you can pull the future from it” (Voroneli, “Ia khochu” 184).

explanatory time self-reference
темечку

Diminutive of “temia” (crown of the head).

register/style
чем ни попадя

Set expression: whatever you can get, is at hand.

phraseologism
дружба крепче да дурость лишнюю вышибает долой

Аллитерация (д, б, л).

sound stylistic device
Супостат

Archaic: adversary.

archaism
на колу

Set expression: on pins and needles (literally: as if impaled).

phraseologism
скуля

Colloquial: to whine, whimper.

register/style
рванулся

Colloquial: to dash, dart, run off.

register/style
Илью

Ilya here refers to himself in the third person. Ilya is Between Dog and Wolf’s protagonist and the author of what he calls the Zaitil’shchina, a long letter with epic traits (starting from its title) addressed to Inspector Pozhilykh in which he comments on the theft of his crutches (he has only one leg) and, more generally, describes life along the Volga River. Johnson defines Ilya’s letter as “semiliterate ramblings,” aptly suggesting the style and register the reader will encounter in the novel (“Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). However, this character expresses at the same time a highly poetic and imaginative gaze. Ilya frequently associates himself with the biblical prophet Elijah, a figure folklorically linked with thunderstorms and which in Slavic tradition acquired some of the characteristics of the pagan God of the sky and thunder, Perun. Ilya is closely related to other key characters of the novel: he describes his troubled relationship with Orina (alternatively called Maria and the Dame) with whom he has a son; in encountering Yakov (the focus of several chapters), he suggests the possibility of being his father. The Oedipal plot resulting from this triangle has been noted by scholars, such as Johnson, who writes that “the game warden Iakov lusts for his mother (reincarnate as a mentally defective girl) and kills his father-all without being aware of the identity of either” (“Twilight Cosmos” 644).

explanatory character folklore intertextuality
доколе

Archaic: as long as.

archaism
ровно черти в амбаре

Like devils in a granary: they get covered in white snow, as devils would in flour.

explanatory
лампада

Poetic: lamp, candle. Typically used in churches as lights before an icon. The term is derived from the name given to Hecate’s companions in Greek mythology. According to various stories, they lead the goddess of witchcraft’s way with lanterns (or other goddesses) and may lead humans to madness or death.

intertextuality register/style religion
чекалка

Same as шакал (jackal). As Ostanin notes, in Egyptian mythology, Anubis, the god of the dead who would ferry the deceased to the underworld, takes the form of a jackal or a man with the head of a jackal. Animal motif.

motif intertextuality religion
дрема хмельная

Alcoholic state of half sleep. Alcohol theme.

explanatory theme
испитóй

Drunk. Alcohol theme.

explanatory theme
судачок

Diminutive of “sudak”, zander. Animal motif.

motif
Итиля

The Tatar name of the river Volga. The title of Ilya’s letter “Zaitil’shchina” is derived from this version of the river’s name. Ostanin also suggests a sound link between the rivers Itil’ and Lethe (Leta), the river of oblivion and forgetting, which also plays a major role in Sokolov’s first novel, A School for Fools (10).

location foreign language setting
прорухи

Low: mistake, blunder. Here: snag, rip, hole, jag.

register/style
волос сечется

According to Boguslawski, a “reference to the folk saying ‘ot radosti kudri v’iutsia, a ot pechali sekutsia’ (From joy the hair is weaving and from sadness it is splitting) (“Annotations” 250).

intertextuality folklore

Possible quotation from Marina Tsvetaeva’s poem “Nikto nichego ne otnial…”. Read it here in Russian and English.

intertextuality
Положа руку на сердце

Set expression: in total honesty.

phraseologism
виктория

Unusual occurrence, instead of “pobeda” (victory). Viktoriia is generally used only as a female given name. Interestingly, the occurrence is closed to the verb “peremog” (past tense of peremoch’, to win over, to defeat someone), which is also the plural genitive of the Ukrainian term for “victory” (peremoga).

language
поведать

Dated: to tell, recount.

register/style
Пожилых

An unusual surname that does not permit standard declination. It literally means Elderly. Ostanin suggests a connection to Boris Pasternak’s novel Doctor Zhivago by means of the root “zhiv” (to live) (10). Read the original here. Likewise, he notes that Alexander Pushkin considered including a story entitled “Notes of an Elderly Person” in his cycle of short stories, The Tales of Belkin. Read the original here and an English translation here. As Martina Napolitano observes, “Pozhilykh, Ilya’s addressee, is once ‘transfigured’ into an alleged Resurrection painting whose title plays on the ambiguity of his last name – Voskresenie Pozhilykh, The Resurrection of the Elderly. Ilya indeed concludes his letter wishing Pozhilykh “a happy resurrection”: this is his final message, his “good news.” It literally is his Gospel, from the Greek εὐαγγέλιον (good news); in the original, Ilya here distorts the canonical blagaia vest’ in ‘blagoe izvestie’” (“Studyin” 286).

intertextuality character religion
в шкуру верим

A possible reference to the Biblical doubting Thomas: according to John’s Gospel, the apostle refused to believe Jesus had been resurrected and asked to see his crucifixion wounds.

intertextuality bible religion
А с холма, с холма высочайшего, словно государев о поблажках указ, пребольшая охота валила вдоль кубарэ, ретируясь из чутких чащ

Another ekphrastic description of The Hunters in the Snow, a 1565 painting by Pieter Bruegel the Elder, the first appearance of which occurs in chapter 2. The setting and action of this image recurs throughout Between Dog and Wolf (e.g., R202–203/E93–95), as they come to life in the text. Elena Kravchenko explains: “Besides the ‘trope’ of the exhibition viewing, the device of ekphrasis, and the ‘gallery’ structure of The Pictures, Sokolov borrows the underlying ‘teleology’ of Musorgskii’s work. Alongside Borodin, Balakirev, Cui, and Rimskii Korsakov, Musorgskii was one of the ‘Mighty Handful’ (‘Moguchaia kuchka’). Created under the patronage of an art critic Vladimir Stasov, it became the hub of a pioneering national style which espoused folklore and the traditions of the peasantry as the new foundation for Russian music. The group was closely connected with and drew inspiration from the Wanderers, an artistic movement […] Iakov is set to communicate a similar idea. He comes to the Volga to grasp and represent the lives of its people. Besides his poetic gift, Iakov is an artist, and it is his works that form the textual gallery of the prose chapters. The gallery ‘entries’ are either demarcated graphically with italics, which signals a title of a painting, or framed by a reference to their pictorial ‘origin’” (The Prose 61). She continues: “It can be argued that Iakov’s representation of human suffering, which constitutes one of the main themes of the novel, and which has been identified as the major moral message of many Brueghel paintings, is modelled not directly on Brueghel but on W. H. Auden’s ekphrasis in his ‘Musée des Beaux Arts’. Running through the images of Brueghel’s The Census at Bethlehem (1566) and The Slaughter of the Innocents (ca. 1564), it culminates in the ekphrasis of Landscape with the Fall of Icarus (ca. 1558)” (The Prose 63). On the presence and role of Bruegel’s imagery and subtext, see also Mario Caramitti’s article “Mul’tfilmy Breigelia.” Beyond these obvious ekphrastic connections between Sokolov’s novel and Bruegel’s painting, these are other points worth noting. For instance, the series from which Hunters in the Snow derives, The Seasons (1565) is divided into six paintings, five of which remain extant. “If a division of the year into six pictures seems strange initially,” Sabine Pénot and Elke Oberthaler write, “this proves to have been a common way of diving the annual cycle in the Netherlands during the period, as early spring and spring and early summer and midsummer were differentiated. The year’s inherently cyclic character relativizes the discussion around the ‘correct’ order of the pictures – which painting represents the beginning and which the end of the series” (214). Much the same may be said about the structure of Between Dog and Wolf, in which the poetic chapters trace the development of seasonal changes, while everything exists in an in-between state (seasons, characters’ identities, etc.). It is also worth noting that, as in Sokolov’s text where strict adherence to geographical reality is not observed, the landscapes depicted in the Seasons paintings are not accurate: “These so-called ‘mixed landscapes’ combine memories of the Alps with typically Flemish motifs” (229). There is something to be said about the way Sokolov, like Bruegel develops a “sheer inexhaustible richness of detail” that inevitably leads to “the limits of visual perception and linguistic representation” (215). One particular detail of the painting, apparently not described by Sokolov in the novel, feels relevant: “Thick icicles have claimed the mill wheel at the right edge and brought it to a halt, as though time itself has frozen” (228). Indeed, time and therefore the characters feel stuck in the world of Between Dog and Wolf.

с холма, с холма

Анафорический повтор.

archaism

Unusual (and mockingly foreign) word. It may derive from the word “kubar’”, informally used by students of the naval academy to define a ship cabin.

foreign neologism location

Archaic: to withdraw from a battle.

archaism
Крылобыл

Krylobyl is a key character dwelling in the world of the dead (living on the other shore of the Itil’ river). It is not surprising given his “speaking name” formed by the words “krylo” (wing) and “byl” (was, used to be). He’s a hypostasis of an angelic creature guiding Ilya in his wanderings and suggesting to him ideas and reflections: in chapter 4 it was Krylobyl who advanced the idea of the origin of the “zhe” letter; it will be Krylobyl in chapter 14 who Ilya describes as a “know-it-all” who “instructs,” the one “whom I trust, whom I praise.” In a sense, Krylobyl is Ilya’s Virgil or, even, Beatrice in his wandering across this very special Inferno, Purgatorio, and Paradiso. Toward the end of the novel, he will be addressed by the narrator in chapter 16 (R275/E220) and by Ilya in chapter 17 as “Fedot Fyodorov” (R279/E227).

character intertextuality intratextuality
Крылобыл на хребтине малую тушку нес

This detail—a hunter with a small animal on his back—does appear in Bruegel’s Hunters in the Snow. Animal motif.

С полем, с полем, охотников я поздравлял. Олем, олем, мрачные они трубят, будто умерли. Очевидно, мороз языки их в правах поразил. С наступающим, я сказал. Ающим, Крылобыл передернул, лающим. Славный, слышь, выдался вечерок, говорю, приятные сумерки. Ок, старик согласился, умерки.

Instead of Lermontov’s generation, whose future seems to the poet either void or dark, Ilya announces a brilliant tomorrow for his peers.

Dated: descendent.

Устаревшее: потомок.

register/style
штатных юродивых

Sasha Sokolov explains that this expression should be intended “in a metaphoric and ironic way.” He adds: “Holy fools and beggars belong to their own group, their own mafia. They live well thanks to charity. By common agreement, each one works in a strictly defined area: one controls the train station, one controls the cemetery, and one sits near the shopping center. The church porch is considered the most profitable place: believers are generous. The most influential and respected holy fools, veterans of the profession, operate on the porch. The porch is the highest level of the career ladder. Having occupied this position, the holy fool becomes an indispensable element of parish life until the end of the century; he becomes almost a staff member of the church, although he is not on any official list and does not receive a salary” (personal communication, July 7, 2023).

Саша Соколов объясняет, что это выражение нужно понимать “в переносном и в ироническом смысле.” Он добавляет к этому: “У юродивых и просто нищих - своя компания, своя мафия. Они неплохо живут благодаря подаяниям. По общему уговору, каждый работает на своем строго определенном участке: тот контролирует вокзал, тот кладбище, а этот - сидит возле торгового центра. Самым доходным местом считает церковная паперть: верующие щедры. На паперти подвизаются самые влиятельные и уважаемые юродивые, ветераны профессии. Паперть - высшая ступень карьерной лестницы. Заняв эту позицию, юродивый до скончания века становится непременным элементом приходской жизни, он делается как бы штатным сотрудником церкви, хотя ни в каком официальном списке не числится и зарплату не получают” (личная переписка, 7 июля 2023).

explanatory character
юродивых

Holy fools or fools-in-Christ. Devoted believers in Christianity who give up their possessions and behave in ways contrary to social standards in order to commit fully to their faith and to demonstrate the hypocrisies of society. Holy fools are common in Russian literature, both in religious texts and secular works.
