intertextuality religion bible
Итиль

The Tatar name of the river Volga. The title of Ilya’s letter “Zaitil’shchina” is derived from this version of the river’s name. Ostanin also suggests a sound link between the rivers Itil’ and Lethe (Leta), the river of oblivion and forgetting, which also plays a major role in Sokolov’s first novel, A School for Fools (10).

location foreign language setting

Stinger (insects’). Animal motif. This could be an allusion to the city of Samara: as you take a look at Volga’s flow, it is precisely in Samara that the course is “stingy.”

motif location Russia
навроде

Low: like.

register/style
косы

Braid, scythe, or sandback/spit. The ambiguity of the word “kosa” has a famous literary “predecessor” in Aleksandr Blok’s drama Balaganchik (The Puppet Show, 1906). The female character of Columbine has a “kosa” behind her back: either a hair braid or a scythe. The “mystics” warn Pierrot about her being Death, but he calls her his bride (“Я не слушаю сказок. Я — простой человек. Вы не обманете меня. Это — Коломбина. Это — моя невеста”; I don’t listen to fairy tales. I am a simple man. You will not deceive me. This is Columbine. This is my bride). The ambiguity is also stressed by the character of the Author who enters the scene and exclaims: “Я не признаю […] аллегорической игры словами: неприлично называть косой смерти женскую косу! Это порочит дамское сословие!” (I do not recognize […] such allegorical wordplay: it is indecent to call a woman’s braid a scythe of death! It denigrates a lady’s status!). In the end, Pierrot sadly discovers that this Columbine was just a “cardboard bride” (Она картонной невестой была). The crucial theme linking a woman’s love to death draws parallels between Sokolov’s novel and Blok’s Balaganchik, although there is a very long literary tradition that has developed this line (e.g., Eros and Thanatos; Catullus’s Odi et amo, I hate and I love). Read the original by Blok here.

intertextuality language theme
пожалте

Low: please.

register/style
сухарь

Literally: a dry, hard biscuit. Colloquial: heartless person.

register/style
точу ли с кем лясы

Set expression (tochit’ liasy): to chit-chat. It overlaps with the first meaning of tochit’, central in the whole book.

phraseologism intratextuality explanatory
Орине

Orina, along with her variants, is the primary female character in the novel. In a sense, she is the only female figure in Between Dog and Wolf. As D.B. Johnson summarizes, the “promiscuous heroine Orina-Mariia is a train dispatcher, a princess in her dispatcher’s tower, who entertains her coworkers in her bed. Some of her orgiastic trysts take place near the train tracks to which her lovers tie her meddling husband Il’ia. Orina, in at least one time dimension, is killed by a train as she belatedly tries to save Il’ia who loses his leg” (“Twilight Cosmos” 647). Ilya is obsessed with this woman, and this passion “is the ultimate source of the woes that befall Il’ia, the itinerant grinder. It is his passion for the faithless slut Orina that brings about his misfortunes: the loss of his leg, his wandering life as a drunken grinder, and the grisly events that lead to his death” (643). Orina, alternatively called Maria, exists in the book also in another version, as ta dama, that dame, “a mysterious woman who appears along the river seeking Il’ia and, failing to find him, takes away a new lover each time […]. Her chance lovers return days later, sexually depleted and without interest in life. They usually die by their own hand” (645). In this figure (which embodies “virtually all female figures in the book,” D.B. Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 211), Sokolov merges two of his major literary themes: sex and death. Thus, Orina, Maria, that dame (ta dama, ta devochka, ta bobylka, ta babulya — all linked by the demonstrative “ta”), “Life Everlastin,” and death in general make up a unique polymorphic character. Smith notices that this female figure “does not appear at all in the verse. The episode of the sexual encounter between this figure and the sailors, which reoccurs obsessively in the prose, is correspondingly absent from the verse passages” (333). Olga Matich suggests the existence of a literary subtext for Sokolov’s novel: “Pilniak’s lesser known story Mother Earth (Mat’ syra zemlia 1927) about the violent confrontation between a naive young Bolshevik and an archaic Volga peasant community at the time of the Civil War. It is a kind of love story between the city-bred Bolshevik and the horse-tanner and young earth mother Arina, impaled by the Cossacks in one of the story’s many violence-ridden episodes. A variation on the Scythian juxtaposition of nature and culture, the story also depicts Arina’s maternal love for a fox cub, whom she tries to tame, thinking it is a wolf” (“Sasha Sokolov and His Literary Context” 312). The name Orina may also carry an echo of Pushkin’s famous nurse Arina Rodionovna (Toker 353). Mario Caramitti proposes three recurring hypostases of ta dama across Sokolov’s novels: a first hypostasis is that of a “mysterious woman carrying an obscure menace and/or sexual temptation”; a second hypostasis is that of an “apparently better defined and concrete woman being the object of desire for the main character”; and the third hypostasis is that of a “child-woman, often mentally retarded, often victim of violences, who touches upon a slightly more sublimated erotic sphere” (“Amore e morte” 114). Caramitti also adds that in the novel one of ta dama’s victims, before or after committing suicide, explicitly calls her “вечная жизнь” (Life Everlastin): “it is precisely in the coitus with eternity, in a region of oblivion that it is most difficult to place on this side or on the other side of the Lethe, that the male protagonist finds the widest surface of contact with this protean female entity of now vast symbolic implications” (118). Among Orina’s many lovers and among the men who take advantage of her, there is also Yakov, her son, who is in a way “re-enacting the role of the lame Oedipus” (Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). In chapter 14, Orina’s patronymic is said to be “Ignat’evna” (daughter of Ignatii): the name Ignatii possibly comes from the Latin “ignis” (fire) (R258/E190). Given that Orina is depicted here through her lust, such a patronymic seems apt. Her last name is said to be alternatively Neklina and Paklina (Spacklin, in translation): “You were called around the barracks Orina Neklina, and to whom do you belong now, to what kind of, let’s suppose, Spacklin, ah?” (R246/E169). On the border with Ukraine, close to Mariupol’ and to Chekhov’s hometown Taganrog, there is Rostov district named Neklinovsky. Paklia and paklina are regional terms indicating different things: a left-handed person, an unhandy and clumsy person, a bony hand, a piece of hemp or coarse fiber, messy hair. The terms паклен and неклен are named for the Tatar maple (note the slight differences in the spelling between the tree names and Orina’s surnames: Неклина, Паклина). As Sokolov explains, “Apparently, the author of the Notes and Ilya know or have heard about a man named Paklin. Ilya says that Arina’s last name was Neklina, probably after one of her men. And now, years later, Ilya assumes, she lives with someone else, whose last name suggests to him the tree’s other name” (personal communication, July 7, 2023).

religion bible intertextuality
даму

Orina, along with her variants, is the primary female character in the novel. In a sense, she is the only female figure in Between Dog and Wolf. As D.B. Johnson summarizes, the “promiscuous heroine Orina-Mariia is a train dispatcher, a princess in her dispatcher’s tower, who entertains her coworkers in her bed. Some of her orgiastic trysts take place near the train tracks to which her lovers tie her meddling husband Il’ia. Orina, in at least one time dimension, is killed by a train as she belatedly tries to save Il’ia who loses his leg” (“Twilight Cosmos” 647). Ilya is obsessed with this woman, and this passion “is the ultimate source of the woes that befall Il’ia, the itinerant grinder. It is his passion for the faithless slut Orina that brings about his misfortunes: the loss of his leg, his wandering life as a drunken grinder, and the grisly events that lead to his death” (643). Orina, alternatively called Maria, exists in the book also in another version, as ta dama, that dame, “a mysterious woman who appears along the river seeking Il’ia and, failing to find him, takes away a new lover each time […]. Her chance lovers return days later, sexually depleted and without interest in life. They usually die by their own hand” (645). In this figure (which embodies “virtually all female figures in the book,” D.B. Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 211), Sokolov merges two of his major literary themes: sex and death. Thus, Orina, Maria, that dame (ta dama, ta devochka, ta bobylka, ta babulya — all linked by the demonstrative “ta”), “Life Everlastin,” and death in general make up a unique polymorphic character. Smith notices that this female figure “does not appear at all in the verse. The episode of the sexual encounter between this figure and the sailors, which reoccurs obsessively in the prose, is correspondingly absent from the verse passages” (333). Olga Matich suggests the existence of a literary subtext for Sokolov’s novel: “Pilniak’s lesser known story Mother Earth (Mat’ syra zemlia 1927) about the violent confrontation between a naive young Bolshevik and an archaic Volga peasant community at the time of the Civil War. It is a kind of love story between the city-bred Bolshevik and the horse-tanner and young earth mother Arina, impaled by the Cossacks in one of the story’s many violence-ridden episodes. A variation on the Scythian juxtaposition of nature and culture, the story also depicts Arina’s maternal love for a fox cub, whom she tries to tame, thinking it is a wolf” (“Sasha Sokolov and His Literary Context” 312). The name Orina may also carry an echo of Pushkin’s famous nurse Arina Rodionovna (Toker 353). Mario Caramitti proposes three recurring hypostases of ta dama across Sokolov’s novels: a first hypostasis is that of a “mysterious woman carrying an obscure menace and/or sexual temptation”; a second hypostasis is that of an “apparently better defined and concrete woman being the object of desire for the main character”; and the third hypostasis is that of a “child-woman, often mentally retarded, often victim of violences, who touches upon a slightly more sublimated erotic sphere” (“Amore e morte” 114). Caramitti also adds that in the novel one of ta dama’s victims, before or after committing suicide, explicitly calls her “вечная жизнь” (Life Everlastin): “it is precisely in the coitus with eternity, in a region of oblivion that it is most difficult to place on this side or on the other side of the Lethe, that the male protagonist finds the widest surface of contact with this protean female entity of now vast symbolic implications” (118). Among Orina’s many lovers and among the men who take advantage of her, there is also Yakov, her son, who is in a way “re-enacting the role of the lame Oedipus” (Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). In chapter 14, Orina’s patronymic is said to be “Ignat’evna” (daughter of Ignatii): the name Ignatii possibly comes from the Latin “ignis” (fire) (R258/E190). Given that Orina is depicted here through her lust, such a patronymic seems apt. Her last name is said to be alternatively Neklina and Paklina (Spacklin, in translation): “You were called around the barracks Orina Neklina, and to whom do you belong now, to what kind of, let’s suppose, Spacklin, ah?” (R246/E169). On the border with Ukraine, close to Mariupol’ and to Chekhov’s hometown Taganrog, there is Rostov district named Neklinovsky. Paklia and paklina are regional terms indicating different things: a left-handed person, an unhandy and clumsy person, a bony hand, a piece of hemp or coarse fiber, messy hair. The terms паклен and неклен are named for the Tatar maple (note the slight differences in the spelling between the tree names and Orina’s surnames: Неклина, Паклина). As Sokolov explains, “Apparently, the author of the Notes and Ilya know or have heard about a man named Paklin. Ilya says that Arina’s last name was Neklina, probably after one of her men. And now, years later, Ilya assumes, she lives with someone else, whose last name suggests to him the tree’s other name” (personal communication, July 7, 2023).

register/style
Потому-то и донимают Илью побасенками запечные эти сверчки. Чуть заслышу — всплывут наши с ней вылазки и поездки по пригородным городкам с кузнечиками.

Sokolov explains: “In a normal country house there are crickets. They usually live behind the stove, where it is warmer. People love their crickets and listen to their songs with pleasure, it is believed that crickets bring happiness to the house. Ilya listens to crickets in the house of his female roommate, and their chirping reminds him of the chirping of grasshoppers, with which he associates country trips when he lived with Orina. Grasshoppers don’t live in big cities, but in small towns, why not?” (personal communication, August 21, 2023). Animal motif.

Соколов объясняет: “В нормальном деревенском доме живут сверчки. Обычно они селятся за печкой, где теплее. Народ любит своих сверчков и с удовольствием слушает их песни, считается, что сверчки приносят счастье в дом. Илья слушает сверчков в доме своей сожительницы, и их стрекот напоминает ему стрекот кузнечиков, с которыми у него ассоциируются загородные поездки в тот период, когда он жил с Ориной. В больших городах кузнечики не живут, а в небольших - отчего бы и нет” (личная переписка, 21 августа 2023).

explanatory Russia motif
донимают

Low: to annoy, bother.

register/style
Илью

Ilya is Between Dog and Wolf’s protagonist and the author of what he calls the Zaitil’shchina, a long letter with epic traits (starting from its title) addressed to Inspector Pozhilykh in which he comments on the theft of his crutches (he has only one leg) and, more generally, describes life along the Volga River. Johnson defines Ilya’s letter as “semiliterate ramblings,” aptly suggesting the style and register the reader will encounter in the novel (“Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). However, this character expresses at the same time a highly poetic and imaginative gaze. Ilya frequently associates himself with the biblical prophet Elijah, a figure folklorically linked with thunderstorms and which in Slavic tradition acquired some of the characteristics of the pagan God of the sky and thunder, Perun. Ilya is closely related to other key characters of the novel: he describes his troubled relationship with Orina (alternatively called Maria and the Dame) with whom he has a son; in encountering Yakov (the focus of several chapters), he suggests the possibility of being his father. The Oedipal plot resulting from this triangle has been noted by scholars, such as Johnson, who writes that “the game warden Iakov lusts for his mother (reincarnate as a mentally defective girl) and kills his father-all without being aware of the identity of either” (“Twilight Cosmos” 644).

Same as шакал (jackal). Ilya mistakes the animal (actually a dog) for a wolf. As Ostanin notes, in Egyptian mythology, Anubis, the god of the dead who would ferry the deceased to the underworld, takes the form of a jackal or a man with the head of a jackal. Animal motif.

Аллитерация (пра, па).

sound stylistic device
бахвал

Colloquial: braggart, trash-talker.

register/style
Городнище

The main setting of the novel: a fictional town on the banks of the Volga River. Also called Gorodnishchi. Derived from the words for town (gorod) and beggar (nishchii). It is the “town of beggars.” Olga Matich writes: “If School for Fools was written against the background of youth prose, Sokolov’s next novel Between Dog and Wolf may be read as the author’s response to village prose, the literary rage of the seventies” (“Sasha Sokolov” 310). Vadim Kreid observes that Gorodnishche, a barracks village of beggars and thieves, resembles an “Anti-Kitezh” (Kitezh being the legendary, mythical city in Russian folklore that only the pure-hearted will have the chance to reach). In Gorodnishche, however, thieves rob beggars, while beggars beg thieves (“Zaitil’shchina” 213). According to Johnson, the living dwell Gorodnishche, while the dead reside on the other side of the river, in Bydogoshch (“Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 209). Johnson also mentions a statement by Sokolov himself: “Sokolov reports that the name is a blend of the dissolute eighteen-century town of Gorodnya described by A. N. Radishchev in his Journey from Petersburg to Moscow and a nearby town called Gorodishche. Thus the time layers of the sixteenth century, the eighteenth century, and a mythic present are all superimposed upon each other – a characteristic technique in the novel” (217).

location setting theme intertextuality folklore
оладье

Oladyi — small, thick fried pancakes made with flour, eggs, milk, salt, sugar, and yeast or baking soda. Typically served with sweet toppings or fillings.

вентерь

A fyke or hoop net: Used to catch fish, a fyke net is made of cylindrical netting that is set into place beneath the water’s surface. It allows fish to enter but makes their exit difficult. Here, women are compared to nets and men to fish. Animal-human motif.

Another variation on Ilya’s unusual last name, which is printed in more than ten different versions in the book. It carries allusions to Cinderella (see L. Sokolov himself explains that by the Volga River “there is a settlement called Melkovo, it stands on the bank of a stream pool, which local people call Melkovsky, but the location of Melkoplesovo does not really exist” (personal communication, June 7, 2023).

Соколов объясняет, что у Волги “есть поселок Мелково, он стоит на берегу плеса, который местные люди называют Мелковским, однако пункта Мелкоплесово в действительности нет” (личное сообщение, 7 июня 2023).

Travels and Adventures is the title of a famous book by Spanish traveller Pero (Pedro) Tafur (15th century).

intertextuality
побеспризорнее

The word “besprizornyj/besprizornik” appeared in the Soviet era, and according to the National corpus of the Russian language, it was typical in print in particular between 1920s-1940s. Literally meaning “unsupervised”, it was usually used to refer to homeless children, orphans. Boris Zhitkov, author of children’s books (1882-1938), wrote a short story titled “Besprizornaya koshka” (Unsupervised cat), published in his volume Rasskazy o zhivotnykh (Short Stories about Animals), 1935.

Lyrics from Mikhail L’vovsky’s song “The train will leave for Tikhoretskaya.” Read the lyrics here. Listen to a recording by Vladimir Vysotsky here. It was made famous by the successful movie The Irony of Fate. Watch the film here. See Smith’s “Underground Songs” for more information and context on this style of music in the Soviet Union. Describing publisher Carl Proffer’s difficulties understanding Sokolov’s drafts of the novel, D. Barton Johnson writes: “Sokolov was surprised at this and later reactions: ‘It was my first clash with reality. I hadn’t even known [the thing] was complex. No idea. I thought I had written on the level that [Vladimir] Vysotskii writes song lyrics’ (DBJ interview June 20, 1983)” (“Background Notes” 339). Railroad theme.

rhythm

The mythical Firebird from Slavic folklore. Read the original here and an English translation here. Here, the Firebird is used metaphoric to refer to a girl and to the potential happiness she would bring (Ziolkowski 415). Animal motif.

motif intertextuality folklore
ботинки

Boots. Another echo of Ilya’s story: the theft of his crutches. D.B. Johnson has identified more than twenty different types of shoes across Sokolov’s three novels: “bashmaki, botforty, boty, botinki (polubotinki), cheboty, chizmy, chubury, galoshi (kaloshi), gety, ichigi, kedy, klogi, lapti, mokrostupy, obuvi (obuvki), sapogi, sandalii, tapochki (polutapochki), shlepantsy, shtiblety, tapti, tufli, valenki. The list may easily be extended with appurtenances such as socks, stockings, footcloths, gaiters, skates, crutches, and artificial legs” (“The Galoshes Manifesto” 156). Regarding Between Dog and Wolf, he notes that Ilya’s last name immediately evokes Cinderella’s vair slippers. Johnson observes that “the footwear motif is Sokolov’s tribute, both conscious and unconscious, to the tradition in Russian literature represented by his predecessors – Ivan Bunin and Valentin Kataev” (179). In an interview with A. and N. Voronel’, Sokolov calls Bunin, along with Gogol, his “contemporaries, collaborators along a chain, older masters” (Voroneli, “Ia khochu” 184). Shoe motif.

This anecdote recalls Ilya’s account of Orina’s work at a railway station, as well as that of Yakov’s dealings with Maria, who also works the rails.

explanatory intratextuality
энском

“N.” A convention of nineteenth-century literature to avoid naming a particular location by replacing it with “N.” For example, the “town of N.”

location explanatory
шлагбауман

A person who mans a schlagbaum (German: slamming down + pole). A pole or bar used to control access to a space. As Boguslawski notes, the narrator puns on schlagbaum and Bauman, “referring to Nikolai Ernestovich Bauman, 1873–1905, a relatively insignificant Bolshevik revolutionary, later turned by the Soviet propaganda into a cult figure” (“Annotations” 251).

foreign explanatory
поручик

Historical term: junior officer rank in the Russian army since the seventeenth century until the October Revolution.

explanatory
корнет

In the pre-revolutionary Russian army, the first officer rank in the cavalry and border guard.

explanatory Russia
корнет, — ноль внимания

According to Ostanin, a reference to Nikolai Nekrasov’s 1846 poem “The Troika”: “Загляделся проезжий корнет” (90). Read the original poem here. Read an English translation here. This figure also appears in Note VI (R170/E36).

The mythical Firebird from Slavic folklore. Read the original here and an English translation here. Margaret Ziolkowski writes: “Here the Firebird has becomes [sic] an explicit metaphor for an evanescent happiness. Moreover, while the folktale Firebird never changes into a person, in Sokolov’s novel the Firebird symbolically acquires a human identity. Thus the traveller did not recognize the real Firebird, who might actually have made his dreams come true, in the woman encountered years before” (415). Animal motif.

Modified lyrics from Mikhail L’vovsky’s song “The train will leave for Tikhoretskaya.” Read the lyrics here. Listen to a recording by Vladimir Vysotsky here. See Smith’s “Underground Songs” for more information and context on this style of music in the Soviet Union. Railroad theme.

metrical pattern

Railway platform.

location
Пел и мучился: ласточка ты моя, на кого покинула, сына забрав и фамилию обменяв ему и себе, и где вы оба сейчас — кто вас ведает

Throughout the novel, Ilya is associated with the hoopoe. In Ovid’s Metamorphoses Tereus is transformed into a hoopoe and searches for his missing family, calling out “where, where” in the bird’s famous song. Therefore, Ilya reenacts this plot as he seeks out Orina and their son, Yakov. Most importantly here, “Ilya closes the loop, so to speak, when he calls Orina ‘you swallow of mine,’ while bemoaning how she took his son from him. He is displaced, like Tereus, in his various transformations and peregrinations, pursuing his idealized family, but constantly mired by the imagery he uses and that is used to describe him” (Vergara, “Flap” 366). Animal-human motif.

motif intertextuality
ласточка

Swallow. Throughout the novel, Ilya is associated with the hoopoe. In Ovid’s Metamorphoses Tereus is transformed into a hoopoe and searches for his missing family, calling out “where, where” in the bird’s famous song. Therefore, Ilya reenacts this plot as he seeks out Orina and their son, Yakov. He is displaced, like Tereus, in his various transformations and peregrinations, pursuing his idealized family, but constantly mired by the imagery he uses and that is used to describe him” (Vergara, “Flap” 366). Animal motif. Animal-human motif.

Я2х2 + Я4.

metrical pattern
Дона

One of Russia’s largest rivers and a major transportation route.

location Russia
клена

Maple. Plant motif.

motif
Величали

Dated: to call.

register/style
Орина Неклина

Orina, along with her variants, is the primary female character in the novel. In a sense, she is the only female figure in Between Dog and Wolf. As D.B. Johnson summarizes, the “promiscuous heroine Orina-Mariia is a train dispatcher, a princess in her dispatcher’s tower, who entertains her coworkers in her bed. Some of her orgiastic trysts take place near the train tracks to which her lovers tie her meddling husband Il’ia. Orina, in at least one time dimension, is killed by a train as she belatedly tries to save Il’ia who loses his leg” (“Twilight Cosmos” 647). Ilya is obsessed with this woman, and this passion “is the ultimate source of the woes that befall Il’ia, the itinerant grinder. It is his passion for the faithless slut Orina that brings about his misfortunes: the loss of his leg, his wandering life as a drunken grinder, and the grisly events that lead to his death” (643). Orina, alternatively called Maria, exists in the book also in another version, as ta dama, that dame, “a mysterious woman who appears along the river seeking Il’ia and, failing to find him, takes away a new lover each time […]. Her chance lovers return days later, sexually depleted and without interest in life. They usually die by their own hand” (645). In this figure (which embodies “virtually all female figures in the book,” D.B. Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 211), Sokolov merges two of his major literary themes: sex and death. Thus, Orina, Maria, that dame (ta dama, ta devochka, ta bobylka, ta babulya — all linked by the demonstrative “ta”), “Life Everlastin,” and death in general make up a unique polymorphic character. Smith notices that this female figure “does not appear at all in the verse. The episode of the sexual encounter between this figure and the sailors, which reoccurs obsessively in the prose, is correspondingly absent from the verse passages” (333). Olga Matich suggests the existence of a literary subtext for Sokolov’s novel: “Pilniak’s lesser known story Mother Earth (Mat’ syra zemlia 1927) about the violent confrontation between a naive young Bolshevik and an archaic Volga peasant community at the time of the Civil War. It is a kind of love story between the city-bred Bolshevik and the horse-tanner and young earth mother Arina, impaled by the Cossacks in one of the story’s many violence-ridden episodes. A variation on the Scythian juxtaposition of nature and culture, the story also depicts Arina’s maternal love for a fox cub, whom she tries to tame, thinking it is a wolf” (“Sasha Sokolov and His Literary Context” 312). The name Orina may also carry an echo of Pushkin’s famous nurse Arina Rodionovna (Toker 353). Mario Caramitti proposes three recurring hypostases of ta dama across Sokolov’s novels: a first hypostasis is that of a “mysterious woman carrying an obscure menace and/or sexual temptation”; a second hypostasis is that of an “apparently better defined and concrete woman being the object of desire for the main character”; and the third hypostasis is that of a “child-woman, often mentally retarded, often victim of violences, who touches upon a slightly more sublimated erotic sphere” (“Amore e morte” 114). Caramitti also adds that in the novel one of ta dama’s victims, before or after committing suicide, explicitly calls her “вечная жизнь” (Life Everlastin): “it is precisely in the coitus with eternity, in a region of oblivion that it is most difficult to place on this side or on the other side of the Lethe, that the male protagonist finds the widest surface of contact with this protean female entity of now vast symbolic implications” (118). Among Orina’s many lovers and among the men who take advantage of her, there is also Yakov, her son, who is in a way “re-enacting the role of the lame Oedipus” (Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). In chapter 14, Orina’s patronymic is said to be “Ignat’evna” (daughter of Ignatii): the name Ignatii possibly comes from the Latin “ignis” (fire) (R258/E190). Given that Orina is depicted here through her lust, such a patronymic seems apt. Her last name is said to be alternatively Neklina and Paklina (Spacklin, in translation): “You were called around the barracks Orina Neklina, and to whom do you belong now, to what kind of, let’s suppose, Spacklin, ah?” (R246/E169). On the border with Ukraine, close to Mariupol’ and to Chekhov’s hometown Taganrog, there is Rostov district named Neklinovsky. Paklia and paklina are regional terms indicating different things: a left-handed person, an unhandy and clumsy person, a bony hand, a piece of hemp or coarse fiber, messy hair. The terms паклен and неклен are named for the Tatar maple (note the slight differences in the spelling between the tree names and Orina’s surnames: Неклина, Паклина). As Sokolov explains, “Apparently, the author of the Notes and Ilya know or have heard about a man named Paklin. Ilya says that Arina’s last name was Neklina, probably after one of her men. And now, years later, Ilya assumes, she lives with someone else, whose last name suggests to him the tree’s other name” (personal communication, July 7, 2023).

character theme intertextuality intratextuality
Паклина

intratextuality character theme intertextuality
смекаешь

Colloquial: to understand, to catch on, realize.

register/style
хоть памятник ставь

He refers to the common monument (tomb) of the Unknown Soldier or, given the book’s context, Sailor (such as the one located in Odessa).

explanatory
матрос Альбатросов

Alliteration.

Аллитерация.

sound stylistic device
Альбатросов

This name calls to mind two famous poetic “albatrosses”: Baudelaire’s (read it here) and Coleridge’s from The Rime of the Ancient Mariner (read it here). Addressing the latter subtext’s image of a bird wrapped around a sailor’s neck in penance, José Vergara writes, “Albatrosov is an embodiment of Ilya’s perceived betrayal by Orina, who it is said, sleeps with a number of sailors under the aforementioned overturned boat on the banks of the Volga, as well as guilt over his own actions. Ilya takes on his sorrow when he meets Albatrosov on a train after his separation from Orina. The avian-sailor thus serves to remind Ilya of the past he cannot escape. […] The anthropomorphized bird imagery, in this way, underscores Ilya’s lingering psychological trauma, both that which he himself caused and that which he received” (“Flap” 372). Animal-human motif. In a 2004 interview with Mario Caramitti, Sokolov comments on the suggestion of art predicting life in mysterious ways mentioning this specific character: “In the winter of 1978 I was living in Michigan and working on my second novel. One of the characters in the book, named Al’batrosov, has a background as a stoker on a ship. I was outlining the character by modeling him on my half-brother, a sailor, who was aboard a freighter at the time. Without thinking about the possible consequences, I made Albatrosov’s fate take a turn for the worse: an explosion in the engine room takes off his arm. When the book came out, I learned that in the same days that I was writing that episode my brother lost an arm to an accident. This is, I would say, the cruelest and most disconcerting example in my practice as a writer. But on the whole what I write often comes true. More often, unfortunately, than I would like, since I generally write about unpleasant things” (“Sokolov, il fabbro pellegrino della prosa russa” 12). The same concept is described by the author in his 1981 essay On Secret Tablets: “things described in fiction come true; fate suggests to the neglected in spirit solutions that it has already found. And it does not make any difference whether the master creates life myths or they create him: the text has been recorded in the same place, on secret tablets. And nothing else but fate will answer all the questions and decide what will remain – silence or the word. And, if necessary, it’ll rip out our sinful tongues” (7).

intertextuality character motif self-reference author
списан вчистую

Set expression: to fire/dismiss someone as permanently unfit, without the right to reinstatement.

phraseologism
по ходу поезда

Set expression: as they go along, little by little. Here (as almost anywhere else in the book) it can also be taken literally, as they travel by train. Railroad theme.

phraseologism theme

This phraseologism is generally used to describe a person with an unstable character. However, the syntagm refers to a folding bag (made of fabric or leather) used to transport things on a horse. This type of bag is also linked with the tradition of bylina, in particular with the character of Svyatogor-bogatyr’. Here the bylina in Russian, and in its English translation. Mentioned already in ch. 4 and 8.

intertextuality bible religion
Илья

Ilya is Between Dog and Wolf’s protagonist and the author of what he calls the Zaitil’shchina, a long letter with epic traits (starting from its title) addressed to Inspector Pozhilykh in which he comments on the theft of his crutches (he has only one leg) and, more generally, describes life along the Volga River. Johnson defines Ilya’s letter as “semiliterate ramblings,” aptly suggesting the style and register the reader will encounter in the novel (“Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). However, this character expresses at the same time a highly poetic and imaginative gaze. Ilya frequently associates himself with the biblical prophet Elijah, a figure folklorically linked with thunderstorms and which in Slavic tradition acquired some of the characteristics of the pagan God of the sky and thunder, Perun. Ilya is closely related to other key characters of the novel: he describes his troubled relationship with Orina (alternatively called Maria and the Dame) with whom he has a son; in encountering Yakov (the focus of several chapters), he suggests the possibility of being his father. The Oedipal plot resulting from this triangle has been noted by scholars, such as Johnson, who writes that “the game warden Iakov lusts for his mother (reincarnate as a mentally defective girl) and kills his father-all without being aware of the identity of either” (“Twilight Cosmos” 644).

хлебнул

говори, говорю

Звуковой повтор (п, л, с, т, р).

sound stylistic device
пляску

Dancing. This word is crucial to Sokolov’s art. Chorea — a movement disorder belonging to the dyskinesias group of neurological disorders. Its name comes from the Ancient Greek “χορεία” and was used to described the movements of those inflicted by the disease. Sokolov’s first novel, A School for Fools, is dedicated to Vita Pliaskina, which refers to Sydenham’s chorea (also known as “St. Vitus’s dance, пляска святого Вита in Russian). Watch a video here. Referred to several times in the novel (R171, 191, 205, 214, 215/E37, 74, 97, 113, 115).

An echo of Anton Chekhov’s 1886 sketch “Ah, Teeth.” Read the original here.

intertextuality
Чего только не перемелет русский дурак за дальнюю дорогу из лазарета в Терем под скрип реборд; перемелет — и станет мука

From the expression “Всё перемелется — мука будет” (Everything will get milled over; there will be flour). An expression of the milling theme in the novel. Sokolov will play with this expression and the difference between му́ка (torment) and мукá (flour) several times.

От выражения: “Всё перемелется — мука будет”. Выражение темы мельницы в романе. Соколов неоднократно обыгрывает это выражение и созвучность муки (страдания) и муки (хлебопекарной).

A tower-room, that is, living quarters in the topmost part of a building shaped like a tower. Common in ancient Rus’:.

Figura etymologica.

sound stylistic device
плясал

Dancing. This word is crucial to Sokolov’s art. Chorea — a movement disorder belonging to the dyskinesias group of neurological disorders. Its name comes from the Ancient Greek “χορεία” and was used to described the movements of those inflicted by the disease. Sokolov’s first novel, A School for Fools, is dedicated to Vita Pliaskina, which refers to Sydenham’s chorea (also known as “St. Vitus’s dance, пляска святого Вита in Russian). Watch a video here. Referred to several times in the novel (R171, 191, 205, 214, 215/E37, 74, 97, 113, 115).

intratextuality intertextuality self-reference
ботинки

Boots. Shoe motif. D.B. Johnson has identified more than twenty different types of shoes across Sokolov’s three novels: “bashmaki, botforty, boty, botinki (polubotinki), cheboty, chizmy, chubury, galoshi (kaloshi), gety, ichigi, kedy, klogi, lapti, mokrostupy, obuvi (obuvki), sapogi, sandalii, tapochki (polutapochki), shlepantsy, shtiblety, tapti, tufli, valenki. The list may easily be extended with appurtenances such as socks, stockings, footcloths, gaiters, skates, crutches, and artificial legs” (“The Galoshes Manifesto” 156). Regarding Between Dog and Wolf, he notes that Ilya’s last name immediately evokes Cinderella’s vair slippers. Johnson observes that “the footwear motif is Sokolov’s tribute, both conscious and unconscious, to the tradition in Russian literature represented by his predecessors – Ivan Bunin and Valentin Kataev” (179). In an interview with A. and N. Voronel’, Sokolov calls Bunin, along with Gogol, his “contemporaries, collaborators along a chain, older masters” (Voroneli, “Ia khochu” 184). Shoe motif.

register/style
кочегарически

Stoker — person who mans the fire for powering a ship (or a building). Here Sokolov plays with the words “kochegar” (stoker) and “kategoricheskii” (categorically), creating a new adverb.

explanatory character neologism language
швабра

Mop. Sokolov explains: “Mop and bulkhead are euphemisms that are often used in the navy along with stronger, more obscene lexicon” (personal communication, July 7, 2023).

Соколов объясняет: “Швабра и переборка - эвфемизмы, которые часто употребляются на флоте наряду с более сильными, нецензурными лексическими единицами” (личная переписка, 7 июля 2023).

explanatory language
